		<username>IDIOTBOX_WEB</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>The Ring without the story.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It must be said that there are two types of horror film. You can prefer the likes of the Texas Chainsaw Massacre with gore and guts or you can prefer the likes of The Ring with strange nightmarish moments. The Grudge walks down the line of The Ring and almost of the edge. I know this film will be criticised by those traditional horror fans who want some people cut up etc but in all honesty horror has evolved. It is much more original and effective these days to have complex camera work that actual scares people rather than grosses them out. The Grudge follows The Ring in so many ways it is untrue, however it does not enjoy the same success. The film does have scares which beat The Ring but lacks the storyline. Perhaps this is a film which just scraps the complex narrative in favour of a catalogue of scares. The intensely horrifying scenes seem to all derive from that final infamous scene from Ring where the entity exits the television set. Originating like The Ring from Japan the similarities are impossible to ignore. The jerky ghosts, the grainy images all are now typical of such Japan style horror. However this does appear to be a welcomed breath of life into a almost dead genre. Traditional slasher horror has truly ran itself out and now seems to just be replicating previous success's with films such as Wrong Turn becoming embarrassingly awful. So The Grudge may have a simply flawed storyline but at least it does what it is intended to do which is scare the audience deeply. In all the movie itself lacks some fundamental elements which firmly placed The Ring as not only a accomplished horror movie but a interesting story. Sarah M Gellar is weak in the story and is not complimented by the other actors and the audience never really emphasises with her due to jerky flashbacks and a split narrative. However this film does have very very scary moments and a strange noise (if you've watched the film you'll know what I'm talking about) that may become infamous among horror fans. In all I give two ratings for this film. General 2/5 Horror 4/5</fullReview>

		<username>J.D. Corcoran</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>More aptly, The Vengeful Victims Won't Move Out: Sketchy premise, scary execution.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Prepare to be genuinely frightened, startled, perhaps terrified. AND that's accomplished with an absolute minimum of blood, guts, and gore. Instead, it is crafted with masterful technique, direction, camera work, and yes, even acting, that is truly nerve-wracking, from the expected moving shadows, reflections in mirrors, a glimpse of a hand or a leg, or a pair of eyes in the darkness. Brrrrrr. The great irony is that the gimmicks you anticipate, you get. BUT it STILL scares the beejeebers out of you.For the horror highbrows, this may be beneath them because there are so many instances of formula fear factors, but for those of us who do NOT go to many movies of this type, it was quite an effective creep-out. A 6'4" 250-pound man to my right was a basket case. The plot? Well, it's a disappointment, and no matter how hard I tried to form some logic out of the jumbled storyline, nothing really adds up to an overall, cohesive plot. I forgive the movie for this because it may be a cultural gap in movie-making technique between American sensibilities and Japanese, where they don't care whether the plot makes sense as long as it looks great and moves like a snake and makes you react. It certainly does do all of those things. Or, perhaps the "plot" problem is mine, as it is a Japanese story written by a Japanese author, and it is just too inscrutable for me rather than inherently incoherent...Sarah Michelle Gellar stars as a college student working for class credit by providing part time care for the infirm. When a fellow worker doesn't report in, Sarah is sent in her place. We the audience already know what's happened to her friend, but not until later do we get to see the grisly details.In a particular house where murder has occurred, evil continues. Who is doing it and why is where the plot goes south. A couple moves their mother into the house and badda-bing, she's practically catatonic. The couple, some police, caregivers, even a cat, fall victim to the convoluted evil that dwells in the house. In fact, on occasion the evil goes lurking elsewhere and rings doorbells, haunts stairwells, sneaks into bed linens, and apparently does so because the target of that traveling malice was in the cursed house at one time or another. As I said, the plot is not the strength of this movie. The execution is, no pun intended.There are flashbacks, an unrequited love psychosis heavy with stalking, noises in the attic and more than enough things that go bump in the night (and day), including some that cling to the ceiling and linger in closets and attics. Talk about the bogeyman under the bed.There are bits and pieces that are certainly lifted from other films, from The Shining (think bathtub), to The Ring (think people compelled against their will to do themselves in). But it's all still SCARY, SCARY, SCARY. If you like goosebumps, don't miss this one.</fullReview>

		<date>2004-11-15</date>
		<username>avalyn11</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>The only movie that has ever succeeded in frightening me</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I like to think of myself as a steeled, seasoned horror movie buff. From the tameness of most of the mainstream films (Nightmare on Elm Street, Halloween, etc.) of the 1980s, to the exploding-zombies/eating-brains Italian fare of the 1970s, to the best/worst of what Japan had to offer since they adopted the horror movie into their cultural identity, I thought I'd seen it all, until I saw The Grudge.It's really no different than many other horror movies, in that it's really just a ghost story. However, it's told from a vastly different perspective, making a very significant departure from the tired ghost story genre. Though the score kind of spoils some of the scares in advance by getting too caught up in itself, every appearance of Toshio and Kayako made me practically jump out of my skin. No movie has ever actually scared me before, until this one did. Just the way Kayako moves, like a cross between a shambling zombie, a dying fish, and a river of hair, she continually appears to devour her victims (or at least scare them witless) in the most unsettling way imaginable. And the scary part is that there's really nothing unique about it; it just works.I have seen the "Ju-On" movies, and they were scary enough, but not enough to make me jump, probably due to their relatively modest budgets. However, the American remake of those movies, with an ample SFX budget, really does it justice. Kayako has gone from tight close-up/lots of makeup to fluid CGI movements, though director Shimizu does stick with the traditional approach at times, which is perhaps what drives the Kayako character, making her into a kind of ultimate movie villain, even though she has no lines and appears for the visual fright aspect only.If you haven't seen the Japanese "Ju-On" movies, you might want to do so before seeing The Grudge, if only to provide a bit more backstory than The Grudge can come up with. All in all, The Grudge is an excellent movie, far from a clumsy American remake of a well-done Japanese original. It's a good movie to see on a date, especially if you or your date scares easily. If you're like me, you'll be half-expecting Kayako to slither out from a closet, or Toshio to be peering up at you from underneath your desk, for weeks afterwards. I give it 4/5 stars, if only for the non-linear storytelling employed by director/writer Shimizu and cinematographers Ettlin and Yamamoto.</fullReview>

		<date>2004-11-15</date>
		<username>pete iwaneczko (peteiwaneczko@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Under-rated genuinely scary film ***Minor Spoilers***</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>First of all, lets get one thing straight, anyone who tells you they weren't at least mildly unnerved by this film is cheating you and themselves. I've been an avid horror fan for over 10 years and this is the closest I've ever been to scared. I'll openly admit that my experience of Japanese horror is somewhat limited. I've seen the US versions of 'The Grudge' and 'The Ring' and The Jap version of 'The Eye' and admit that so far the US versions are winning - quite easily, and this is thanks mostly to this film.From the first 10 minutes of the film, you realize that the story will be basic and I see no problem with this, after all its a horror film not a murder mystery! Man kills wife and child in his home, wife and child haunt the house and, anyone who enters it, until the point of death. So, if the story is nothing unusual, how does this film stand out? Well, it's in the way that the director 'bends' the rules of conventional horror films.For starters, if Jane Doe escapes Haunted House, she's safe, right? Not in this flick. The ghosts have just as much power outside the house and are instantly scarier for this. Also the fact that there is a part of the film, as scary as most others, which occurs in broad daylight! Daytime is virtually always perceived as the time when the suspense builds towards a moonlight fright and this simple twist of the 'rules' ensures that you won't relax at any point of the film. But for me, one simple aspect of the film proves the most frightening. I have always judged the fear factor of a film, not by the amount of times I jumped, but by the psychological fear it instills. Any film which features loud bangs or stillness interrupted by a quick movement could claim to be 'scary', but a film that has you looking over your shoulder is a rare thing. I wasn't bothered as much by the ghost of the young boy, who appeared, to be honest as a young Japanese boy wearing grey make-up, as I was of his mother. Although she appears as a middle-aged Japanese woman, her expressions at times appear to be not those of a human being. I suppose this is testament to her acting ability and the skill of the make-up department. This along with a haunting musical score and a throat-scratching noise which accompanies her appearance, make her scenes the highlight of the film.The scene where the detective is watching the security camera, is one of the most brilliantly terrifying moments in cinema history that I can think of, even now bringing goose bumps to my neck as I write this. The movement of the girl is strange on its own, but as she appears only as a shadow with no features, and as she walks past the camera out of view, both the actor and the viewer release a tightly held breath. ******SPOILER***************** Then the screen turns black and the two most piercingly focused eyes appear on the screen, and I swear they look right at you. This has as much affect on you as it does on the character in the story. This movie does share a lot in common with 'The Ring'. The impending sense of doom, the fact that there is no escape and even the appearance and movements of the wife seem almost identical to those of the girl in this other film, but The Grudge does have enough originality to be considered on its own merits. Whereas 'The Ring' builds steadily to one genuinely scary moment, The Grudge begins by scaring the hell out of you and never lets go. (Which is worse? The ghost behind the Japanese lady in the attic or the fact that you see her a split second before she does?) If I was to point out one criticism, it would be the ending. It feels almost as if the director got bored and decided to stick one last scare in, rather than give us a truly deserving finish to this surprisingly refreshing fright fest. 'The Grudge' does leave a few questions unanswered, but this strangely adds to the eerie feel of the film and should in no way detract from your enjoyment of it. I have yet to speak to a single person who didn't find this at least slightly scary or indeed enjoyable and I am still puzzled, even now, as to how such a tired genre and so many borrowed ideas could produce such a unique film.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2004-11-13</date>
		<username>theantigaz</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Dull</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The Grudge starts off quite promising. It lays down little tid-bits of plot, teases the audience with a few false 'jumps' and then throws in a few shock moments to keep us on our toes. All standard Horror movie procedure stemming from the work done by the masters like Hitchcock back in the day. Unfortunetely the Grudge soon runs out of steam. Instead of building upto a finale and the bombarding the audience with terror and suspense, it just keeps giving little bits away until the end, when it abruptly finishes with little explanation. The plot (here be spoilers, sort of) is basically, people die in house while angry/scared, everyone else who goes in house from that point on dies too. That's all the explanation/plot development you really get.Some of the 'shock' set pieces are well executed, but its the same formula again and again and by the end of the film you know what to expect and it looses its impact. The character development is dire. Sarah Michelle Gellar is the 'star' but all we find out about her character is she is a nurse, she goes to a 'haunted' house. That's it. Most of the character development is devoted to the back story, leaving the main characters so underdeveloped that you don't care what happens to them.IMHO the first 45 mins were quite good, if the director had built on this and led to a big finale with a shocking/exciting/action/un-expected/gory (any would do) for the last 25 mins or so, I would have enjoyed this film. Instead we get a drawn out tale, constantly re-iterating the simple premise of the plot but never explaining how or why things are happening in enough detail to make the audience think. The result is by the time you reach the middle of the film you are bored to tears. This film is dull and not scary.I think this film had a lot of potential but fell short on the homestretch. 2/5.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2004-11-13</date>
		<username>Steve Farrell</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Almost the perfect horror movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The Grudge is a film that starts as it means to go on - a man jumps to his death from the balcony of his apartment. As you might expect, it turns out that this man is, in fact, the key to everything. I'm not going to say exactly how, because spoiling the movie is never a good thing. I'm just saying, he's important. The Grudge is almost the perfect horror movie. It's scary, chilling, without being blindingly obvious (there's exactly one moment of obvious visceral gore in the entire film); most of the scares are subtle, based around a noise, a shadow, a brief vision of something lurking. Perhaps some parts are obvious in the sense of holding up a big neon sign that says 'LOOK! SCARY THINGS HAPPENING!' but somehow, I don't know how, but somehow it doesn't matter. In fact, it adds to the atmosphere. If you're dead and p*ssed, you're not going to be subtle once you've found your target. These aren't some wimpy chain-rattlers. They're dead as hell and they're not going to take it anymore. The Grudge is a truly creepy movie that makes the two films it's been compared to - Amityville Horror and The Haunting Of Hill House - look like Daffy Duck cartoons. Onto the actors. Sarah Michelle Gellar has, in my opinion, been pretty useless in everything she's done that's not Buffy, and she was often outdone by her costars in that. Until now. Her portrayal of care worker Karen shows cinema audiences for the first time the range that SMG is truly capable of. But it is the largely wordless Yuya Ozeki and Takako Fuji - as the ghosts - that steal the movie. They inject chills into the movie just by... opening their eyes a certain way, or opening their mouths. If you'll pardon the pun, the two Japanese actors are the spirit of the movie. Honourable mention to Bill Pullman as Peter Kirk, aka Guy Who's Fault Everything Is, Really.Of course, it's difficult to watch this movie - a Hollywood remake of a Japanese horror - without comparing it to The Ring. But apart from it being based around a p*ssed off dead person, there's not much to compare - there's an obvious rip-off homage to The Ring at one point, though - you'll see what I mean - but this is actually, as far as I'm aware, truer to the original movie's atmosphere than the remake of The Ring was. Oh, and by the way, if you still haven't "got" The Ring - she was evil before she died. Anyway, The Grudge is scarier than The Ring. The film's real weak point is it's backstory - I won't go into it, for obvious reasons, but basically it's about a jealous husband killing his wife. Standard Hollywood fare, except that usually the wife doesn't return from the grave and start - literally - scaring people to death. And perhaps we could have done with some more exposition to explain this, but, oh well.It's a very interesting film. And it doesn't end all happily, with everything tied up in a neat little package, which to my mind is a good thing.</fullReview>
	</review>

The film makers reach boundaries of human senses.But, this film will have audiences running and screaming out of theaters. It will be uncomfortable for the vast majority of people.If you want to watch an entertaining horror film, go see Dracula, or alien instead.As a film one may give it an 8 out of 10. 		<shortDescription>Review of the Grudge</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Forget the plot of the film, and you have what turns out to be one of the most visually frightening films I've seen in a long while. Reminiscent of David Lynch (lack of dialogue; long, dark shots to seemingly nowhere) and--naturally--the original "Ju-On: The Grudge", this was a movie that was provided no easy answers to any questions that it asked. What happens to the police investigator? Was there funny bidness going on with Bill Pullman and his student? I left wanting more, and instead of faulting the movie for it, I was excited to actually HAVE questions that I wanted answers to.One other compliment to the film was the lack of "jump-out-and-scare-you" tricks it used. Of course, they were there, but what was scarier: When Yoko actually sees the girl in the attic, or when she's turning around, lighter in hand, and YOU see her first?</fullReview>

		<username>shadowman21</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Brought back my old fears.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Having read what all most of you Western patrons of the movie have said, I have to say as an Asian that they have been quite fair on the movie. Okay, at the time that the original Ju-On was being shown in theaters, I was still into Western and Korean horror(Tale Of Two Sisters, White Room, etc.) I was so not into Japanese horror. Well, Ju-On got such good ratings here, that I regretted not ever having given it the chance in the theaters. However the Grudge came on here, giving me a second chance to see it,and of course since it was gonna have foreign cast in it, I was more eager. Boy was I glad I sat down in the studios two days ago. That movie just made me wish I had chosen a weekend to watch it. The thing about Asians is that we got such imaginations, that we always are ready to for the scare when comes to these sort of movies. A lot of supposedly lame horror movies that have got received lame theater feedbacks in the West have received quite the opposite this side of the world. Overall the movie was really scary. Of course that has to do with the fact I was the only one sitting in the front section(5th row) of the movie-hall, while rest of them scaredy cats were all huddled in the back(even though when I checked the computer screen during ticket purchasing, a lot of the front rows had been taken). With no one but myself to brace for during the creepy scenes,I had my eyes closed almost half the time. Boy I think I missed a lot of the scenes, especially the scene where that Ju-On chick was giving us a view of her face on the security camera. Was it her or something else there? I never found out. The scene where the little boy opens his mouth and starts yowling like a cat when Peter was looking out the window was also creepy. As a result of this movie I've been sleeping with the lights on till 6:30p.m. for the past two days. That just shows how much realism this movie has. Just a few questions. Whatever happened to the Japanese husband? How come we don't see his ghost? How come Sarah Michelle Gellar is the only one that keeps getting those psychic premonitions of the past occurrences in that house? Are the Ju-On mother and child aware of each other's presence? They seem quite independent of each other in handling the scaring. Will there be a part2? I'm certainly keeping my fingers crossed on that one. Anyone who hasn't seen the film, got see it. It'll change your views of your ethereal surroundings completely. Believe me.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>First, the movie overall was pretty good. Creepy and had some great visuals, but for horror buffs, it is very predictable with the usual jumps and scary music. Like why would Matt's sister run into a long, empty staircase after being scared by a noise. Why does everyone venture around the haunted house after hearing sounds? What would possess Yoko to climb up into someone else's closet with a lighter to investigate a weird scratching sound. Who does that? People looking to get killed?Then there are the plot holes, which I'm guessing maybe filled in the sequel (yeah, it's coming). Here's few:* What happened to Matt's sister, they never found anything in her apartment?* The police detective entered the house, what happened to him?*What about the real estate guy? He was touched by the entity.*Why was the Professor's wife dressed up and madeup like a hooker when Karen went by? You can tell by the photos of her that she's usually very conservative. Some deleted sequences perhaps?*Who pulls tape off a closet at someone else's house after hearing a noise? Who in reality does these crazy things?This movie was decent, not as good as The Ring (look out for the sequel). The whole Japanese atmosphere was unsettling and there are some great scenes and imagery that will make you jump (not me, but I saw others). Decent, but flawed.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2004-11-08</date>
		<username>jon.h.ochiai (jochiai@socal.rr.com)</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Really Didn't Care</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I went to a screening of Takashi Shimizu's "The Grudge" at the USC Film School. The screening also included a question and answer session with the Screen Writer, Steven Susco, which was very cool. I met Steven-- he is a great guy and talented. As context, Susco really adapted the story of Shimizu's "two" "Grudge" movies that were produced in Japan. In this American version of "The Grudge", Susco attempted to fill in some of the narrative or contextual gaps that plagued the original films-- which were otherwise very popular and successful in Japan. Susco worked with Shimizu on the screenplay, and Shimizu also directs this remake of his original work. As part of the post-screening discussion, Susco related a story involving the reason for a certain character making a particular sound. We then all realized that reason was not revealed in the movie-- which was very annoying. Realize this is taken contextually. The other rather interesting insight, was the point of view that in Japanese horror movies as opposed to American, the protagonist does not necessarily find a resolution in Act III. That maybe an oversimplification of Japanese culture, but it is an interesting point. Even with it's shocking opening sequence with Bill Pullman as Professor Peter Kirk, and his wife played by Rosa Blasi, "The Grudge" does it's very best to scare from abrupt sounds and sights, and creepy imagery. The production values are solid. I suppose it is all scary, but the fact that you never have an emotional investment or affinity for the lead character is truly scary. In this the movie ultimately fails, because you never really care about Sarah Michelle Gellar's Karen Davis. Her Karen Davis is a university student in Tokyo who is caught up in perpetuating curse or "grudge". She is thrust upon this fate when she substitutes as caretaker of an ailing and aged woman, whose family are also Americans living in Tokyo. Shimizu and Susco interleave flashback and visions to explain some of what happened. In all of it, Gellar's Karen comes off as the complete "victim", and there is nothing really heroic in her actions. This is where "The Grudge" really didn't work for me. Granted this not really Gellar's doing, and more a pitfall of the story-- there is nothing courageous in the fight. And if hopeless was the intended message of this movie, then that is disappointing and not at all inspiring.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

		<fullReview>After reading some of the reviews posted here before going to see this movie, I felt I was about to go see a bad-to-mediocre ghost story that, while creepy, had no genuine scares.I was pleasantly surprised.Whether you find this movie "scary" or not depends on what types of situations tend to get under your skin; with me, it was the idea that the movie played out almost like a nightmare at times that got me rattled. There is NO indication when this cut happens, so you will get confused if you aren't prepared for this. Some of the people that didn't "get" the movie probably fell victim to this.</fullReview>

Her curiosity leads her to the discovery of a young boy taped inside a closet. The boy is in fact a spirit who is responsible for a terrifying supernatural force that possesses the house and frightens and destroys anyone who goes near it. Several lives are lost before she can discover the truth behind the evil goings-on.Japanese director Takashi Schimizu remakes his own horror film, "Ju-On: The Grudge" with the financial backing of American producers. The emerging picture is your standard haunted house shocker and by today's standards it is pretty tame when one considers the level of gore our eyes have been assaulted with in recent times. Unfortunately, Sarah Michelle Gellar is lacking the dramatic range in order to make us fully sympathise with her plight, but I'm sure that her acting talent will increase when she gains more experience. However, the picture does manage to deliver a few neat shocks that will have audiences shuddering in their seats and once the complicated script gets going, it delivers it's plot twists with a fair amount of skill.</fullReview>

Like a great many people, I'm always suspicious of the artistic motivation behind re-makes, but Shimizu's been hacking away at this little gem for a few years, so the guy should certainly be allowed his big US cash-in on the very finest horror movie of all time. This is essentially a greatest hits compilation from the 2 TV movies and Japanese theatrical releases with the bland (but financially astute) addition of Buffy to pull the mainstream punters. The plot will possibly (?) confuse first timers a little bit as,despite being more conventionally linear than Ju:on , the story is shifted around so that there is only a limited exposition of what actually happened in Kayako's family near the end. Still, nice to see one wonderful scene re-instated from the earliest incarnation of the series (I'll just say the word "jaw" here), and the other bits done reasonably well, although the climatic moments and the shower scene just don't quite seem to have the oomph of the real Ju:on. Kayako is as frightening and compulsive as ever (has her voice got deeper in this one though ????) and the American characters are just as silly as the ones they replaced in the original with the famously daft "hiding in bed" scene re-done here for example....Hopefully this classy "summary" film will encourage more people to seek out the originals (ideally to demand them back in theaters), although I suspect that, as with "The" Ring, some will prefer the mildly processed cheese cover version.Grudge 04 is a worth addition to the series (though buy no means the best) and should provide a great deal of well deserved coinage for all involved to continue scaring the Kayako out of us for a good while to come. 8/10</fullReview>

		<username>FilmOtaku (ssampon@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Effectively scary</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>*Possible Spoilers*A lot of people are going to argue with me on this one, but I thought 'The Grudge' was pretty damn scary. Granted, I'm kind of a fraidy cat, but I'm generally a wuss when it comes to scary imagery and general creepiness; and 'The Grudge' was full of that. Directed by Takashi Shimizu (who also directed the original Japanese version 'Ju-On: The Grudge'), 'The Grudge' is about a bunch of Americans living in Japan who all come across a house that is cursed, thereby cursing themselves. It starts with an American couple who move in with the husband's mother. After the caregiver for the invalid mother goes missing one day, Kare, (the horribly vapid Sarah Michelle Gellar) a nursing student, takes over for the day and the fun begins.'The Grudge' is told in a non-linear style, which is somewhat confusing. It is hard to tell how much time has passed between events. Also, there are a couple of things that are either left unexplained or inconclusive (the fate of the meowing child three years ago comes to mind). However, when you take 'The Grudge' for what it was meant to be, a spooky/scary film, it is certainly effective. Combining surprise scares with creepy imagery, Shimizu not only threatens to scare the pants off of the viewer, but threatens to have you wet them first. Unfortunately there were a couple of shots that were ruined by being featured in the trailer, such as the meowing kid and the now famous 'shower scene', but there were some things that surprised the hell out of me and caused me to take issue with going to sleep that night, especially in my bed. And that is probably the best thing about the film; as Hitchcock did forty years ago with 'Psycho' (and no, I am not remotely comparing 'Psycho' or Hitchcock to 'The Grudge' or Shimizu), ordinary or 'safe' places were no longer safe in 'The Grudge'. If the house is cursed, why should anything happen outside of the house? Right? Wrong.No, 'The Grudge' is not a bastion of superb film-making or even a great horror film, but it is effective and did what it set out to do ? either scared some people (like me) or made a lot of people have a hell of a lot of fun at the movies (everyone else who saw the film with me). I feel that the mission was adequately accomplished, and therefore, I give it a 5/10.Shelly</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>But it is a little better. The Americanized 'The Ring' was tempered down enough to make it more palatable for US audiences. 'The Grudge', I can only assume is the same way, yet by staying more true to its original roots (including keeping the director of the original), it packs a few genuine shocks into what is basically a weak and hole filled plot.Plot line is fairly simple haunted house type stuff. A family lives in this house, father one night kills wife and child in a rage and according to Japanese legend, when a person dies in a sorrowful or rage filled condition, their energy stays behind. Flash forward three years, a young American couple, his mother and sister all move to Japan, and all step foot in the house. All three are subjected to the ravages of the curse. Enter a young Japanese health care worker, and she too falls victim to the evil within. Then enters Sarah Michelle Gellar's character, a young transplanted American who fills in for the mysteriously missing Japanese worker (of course, we all know what happened to her) and becomes aware that something is wrong. During the course of the rest of the film we're treated to basically a flashback sequence that explains the story of the curse, how it ties in and how SMG's character fits in. Director Takashi Shimizu has created a beautiful and wonderfully atmospheric film, the cold creepy look and feel offer much in its favor, but the weak story doesn't hold up to the many questions it leaves unanswered. Acting here is decent enough, not outstanding, but I can't really complain about anything either. Bill Pullman in particular is good as an American professor who figures quite prominently in the story. Far too many unanswered questions dot this film, yet when you're sitting in a dark theater in the heat of the moment, 'The Grudge' packs enough creeps and shocks to make it worthwhile enough.2 out of 5</fullReview>

The house, once the scene of a violent crime, is haunted by a dead woman and her dead son. 		<shortDescription>A letdown</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Sarah Michelle Gellar stars in this, the fifth time the Ju-On tale has been told, with the original writer/director crafting his spooky tale for a western audience. The film introduces us to a house where something happened, causing spirits to haunt it. Anyone who enters the house will soon die, as the curse gets to them. SMG plays a student social care worker who is assigned to look after an old lady in the house. Creepy, atmospheric, chilling, and excellent use of camera-work and sound....that was the Japanese version which was out earlier this year. This remake unfortunately lets itself down by using the Hollywood conventions of building music to let us know something is going to happen, blaring noise to make us jump (why, I don't know), and tricky/jumpy camera-work to add a disturbing edge to the film...thus dampening the overall effect.The camera-work is the biggest problem. One brilliant scene in the original, of the female spirit crawling down the stairs showed the full journey step by step. Here, we see her at the top, a quick glimpse at the middle, then she is at the bottom (whilst rising music tells us we should be scared). The scene loses the whole effect in making it so quick. It isn't a total failure. Like The Ring, it is better than most of the usual garbage Hollywood churns out these days, and is a reasonable translation of the story. It's just that once again the essence of what makes Ju-On so chilling has gone. This is even more distressing when you remember the original creator was in charge. WHy did he change his vision so much? Why did he decide to go conventional Hollywood? Above average, but a letdown at the same time. Go watch the original instead.</fullReview>

		<date>2004-11-02</date>
		<username>corok40-all</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>An original and a Flawed Remake</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Oddly enough, I've just found myself having seen both the original Japanese and American remake versions of 'The Grudge' and the experience is a very strange one. Watching both within days of one another is like seeing what happens when you look into a kaleidoscope after you find out how one works: you know that it's only mirrors reflecting off of one another that make the patterns that form the image even as you are aware that there is a simplicity at the heart of the thing that may tell you that there is less here than meets the eye.In it's original incarnation, Takashi Shimizu's, Ju-on: the Grudge, like his earlier movie, 'Ringu (in the U.S. remake, 'the Ring)' is a bold and effective shocker that demonstrates his deep understanding of genre, image, audience and technique. His talent is very great in the Japanese original--it shines through in the Hollywood remake--but what springs from it may be an acquired taste.Ju-on, is an anthology of terror tales that stem from various people entering a house in which a passionate multiple murder had been committed. No spoilers are necessary and none are possible. That is all there is to the movie;. there is no sex, no love interests, no conflict and almost no character development (long before the action and subtitles allow you to figure out someone's job description, they're toast). In fact there is no meaningful conflict to speak of at all. In this sense, Ju-on's tales of terror aren't really tales at all--at least not 'tales' in any sense that a class in fiction writing would impress on you, because in order for you to have a tale, you have to have a character with known qualities struggle against something (here: death in a state of absolute terror) and either fail or succeed--win or lose. Ju-on's writing skips over the sense that the victims--who, by the way, pile up like chord wood--ever had a chance, or that they had the presence of mind to look for one.On the other hand, Ju-on doesn't require a plot to be effective. Shimizu's sense of image and his smooth injection of Japanese Ghost Story imagery into a modern setting is genuine, fresh and original. Japan has a longstanding love affair and a very well-explored style of the supernatural, with literal centuries of artwork devoted to nightmarish imagery. Japanese ghosts and spirits are otherworldly in senses that are alien to western traditions and the Japanese notion of haunting in fiction and traditional tales is often more intense than its western counterpart in that it is more open.Better still for shocker junkies, Shimizu redefines and modernizes his traditional ghost images for a twenty-first century setting in subtle and exciting ways: in Ju-on: the Grudge, Shimizu's ghosts are spirits of terror and malice and nothing is more appropriate to this than murderous spirits that are aware of security cameras or that make otherworldly sounds through their victim's cell-phones. It's touches like this that show that Shimizu's depth of imagery goes far beyond mere recitation of what for him are well-understood themes, and this goes far to make up for his terrific lack of plotting--both in his original Japanese work and in the U.S. remake.The American remake in theaters at the time of this writing, 'The Grudge,' is an attempt to capitalize on the cult following that Ju-on: the Grudge has found in the west while at the same time adding and subtracting those parts of the original that a Hollywood audience finds least comfortable.To this end, the U.S. version, which, like the original is set entirely in Japan, tries to make up for what a Western audience would see as lacunae by adding five things:1. A focus in the story on an instantly recognizable U.S. movie/television star ('The TV series, 'Buffy the Vampire Slayer's, Sarah Michelle Geller) as Karen.2. A romantic interest in SMG's boyfriend, a student3. A set of scenes meant to give an understandable and palatable reason for the gigantic malice of the spirits in question.4. A much bigger special-effects budget.5. A plot.The results are mixed. Instead of playing on the original's strengths, by keeping and perhaps even broadening the original's anthology format, the U.S. version tries to fill up time with extended character development (in people who've got less than ten minutes of screen-time to live) and by focusing on SMG running around Tokyo trying to learn about the house and its mysteries.By rewriting the original to play to a Western style of writing movies, the writers and producers take a big chance. By eliminating the point of the original movie's writing--an episodic exercise in generating a body-count--the powers that be behind the remake drop the main attraction of Shimizu's original which can be expressed in by the words 'sheer volume.'All in all, I find the original a lot easier to watch than I found the remake. I like Sarah Michelle Geller, but after years of watching 'Buffy the Vampire Slayer,' it's hard to accept her in the role the movie gives her.4.5/10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Why?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Hollywood has a terrible habit at the moment. They take great Japanese horror films, relocate them, put 'stars' in them, and obviously strip away all the subtitles. 'The Grudge' has the edge over recent US remakes here as it only stumbles into one of those 'dumbing down' pitfalls, placing Sarah 'Buffy' Michelle Gellar into the heroines role.The story goes that the Japanese say when a person dies in terrible circumstances they hold a grudge and take revenge on anyone who comes into contact with the place they died. A young mother and her child were murdered by the mothers jealous husband in a house in the Tokyo suburbs. Three years later the house is rented out to an American couple and the husbands invalid mother who have come to Tokyo for work. They hire help to look after the mother, but the first girl that arrives disappears after her first visit. Her replacement is Karen Davis, a foreign exchange student (played by Gellar) in need of a Social Work credit.The film still takes place in Japan, and it still has a lot of subtitles. The story is almost exactly the same as the original 'Ju-On : The Grudge', and the set is exactly the same, using exactly the same house as the original. The Japanese actors have been re-employed. This all begs the question... why? I assume Hollywood still has a misconception that the Western cinema-going public won't go to see a film unless it stars someone they "know". The suits should look at the success of films such as 'Hero', 'City of God' and 'Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon' to realize that this is not the case. If a foreign film is good enough the suits should give the public some credit by giving the original film a full scale mainstream cinema release. I am hoping other studios take note of Miramax doing just that with 'Hero' and in future follow their lead with foreign language films.Back to the film itself. The story is reasonably good if you haven't seen the original, and the director (Takashi Shimizu, the director of the original) manages to steer well clear of the usual US horror clichés and cheese and delivers a solid genre film that relies on creeping tension rather than gore to deliver its shocks. Hollywood take note.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>Basically an American remake of the recent Japanese film JU-ON, this works best on reduced expectations.JU-ON made points with its atmospheric backdrop and retreating narrative line; THE GRUDGE contains more outright scares, but also makes less sense as a plot. 		<date>2004-10-30</date>
		<username>anhedonia</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Lost in translation</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I'm always wary of remakes.More often than not, they're never as good as the original. I'm even more skeptical of foreign filmmakers who agree to remake their movies for an American studio. It sounds like a good idea to keep the original director, but just as Hong Kong filmmakers John Woo, Ringo Lam and Tsui Hark were forced to water down their action film-making when they came to Hollywood, foreign directors seem to lose their artistic integrity when remaking their films for Hollywood. Remember what happened when George Sluizer remade his 1988 film, "The Vanishing," for American audiences five years later? He turned a brilliant psychological thriller into a pedestrian Hollywood film and tacked on a happy ending, to boot.Nevertheless, I was eager to see what Japanese director Takashi Shimuzu would do with his remake of "The Grudge." There are two things initially going for this film. One, despite starring American actors, the story remains in Japan, thereby creating potential to tap into differences in horror mythology. Two, "The Grudge" remake opens with a doozy of a scene involving Bill Pullman.Alas, after that, there's really nothing much more to this film. Part of the problem could be that while Shimuzu's original was rated R, the remake is PG-13. Japanese horror films depend much more on creating an eerie atmosphere than loading up the gore. It's a great device, since they often prey on our fear of the unknown.But this film does not tap into the cultural differences between America and Japan and does not delve into the psychological traps that each culture's folklore creates. True, there are some genuine shocks in this American remake. But none of the characters is very interesting and, despite its origins, "The Grudge" turns into just a typical Hollywood horror with characters doing dumb things like sticking their heads into dark crevices to find out if there's anything in there. You want to hazard a guess as to what happens? There's also a character who winds up in an office stairwell, hears strange noises and promptly yells, "Is anyone there?" In the history of horror films, has there ever been a reply to that question?The biggest disappointment with "The Grudge" is that Shimuzu and screenwriter Stephen Susco reveal the story's terrifying monster early. Once we've seen it, there's no more reason to fear it. So while the characters all seem scared of it, for us, the terror's more laughable than scary.The nonlinear structure isn't distracting, but it seems more gimmicky than anything else. And the horror scenes appear to work outside the story - you could easily shift the frightening scenes around in any order and it wouldn't make any difference to the plot or film. The movie's most terrifying moment belongs not to Sarah Michelle Gellar's Karen, but to KaDee Strickland's Susan Williams as she's tracked from her high-rise office to her apartment."The Grudge" spends so much time pretending to be scary that it loses much of its edge. The monsters aren't all that frightening once we see them and, after a while, I just wanted Gellar to turn into Buffy Summers. She wouldn't have put up with all this nonsense. She'd have just kicked the crap out of them. And that would have made the film a lot more entertaining and enjoyable.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2004-10-29</date>
		<username>cobbler88</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>'The Ring,' but lesser (spoilers)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The viewing experience in "The Grudge" is almost identical to "The Ring." In neither movie is there really much of a payoff for the viewer at the end in terms of actually bothering to take care of any of the loose ends. I thought both films were "jumpers" that had me in goosebumps at times ... for the first few instances that called for it. At least in "The Ring," there is some plot development and search into a complex history to explain what is going on before they disappoint the viewer. In "The Grudge," the back story isn't complicated at all, and explanations are still in short supply. First, why are the original innocent victims suddenly murderous ghosts? I imagine they're not thrilled by the way they left the mortal coil, but that doesn't really explain why they just keep killing ... and killing. Besides, logic following, wouldn't the new victims also become murderous? There wouldn't be anyone left on the planet after a week, which might explain why ...... apparently there are only around 2,000 people living in Tokyo, which I believe this was set in. Every time anyone's pursued, every street, hallway, parking lot and corridor is completely devoid of people. In a huge office building at night, the only two people there are a security guard and a transplanted American? And has anyone heard of light switches? Most of the time, characters don't even attempt to turn on lights when they investigate strange noises. They just walk, scared, into dimly-lit rooms or crawl spaces. 'Also, for a haunted house flick, the murderous apparitions are able to do a surprising amount of traveling about town to claim their victims.Ultimately, like "The Ring," "The Grudge" starts out promising, but leaves many viewers feeling cheated at the end. I hesitate to call the latter a clone of the former, though. I'm not an expert on Japanese culture or cinema, but it's entirely possible that their view of what makes for suspense is simply different than our own. Maybe, as Americans, we want too much bundled neatly in a package by the end of a movie.But I believe this movie fell short in that it failed to explain the simplest thing in a horror movie, which is why, logically, the slayers are killing people.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>alle3377</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>heckle this movie. Everybody did</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>OK, the movie is predictable and there is no ending. The beginning is mysterious. *Spoilers*. I'm going to focus on two aspects of the movie. The first is, there is a house in tokyo that's haunted. A violent murder by a husband on his wife and child had been committed in the house. Innocent people that enter the house (as you'll notice as the movie progresses) will obviously die no matter where they are by the child and woman.I guess this happens only in Japan (kinda like the big monster movies). OK, here's the problem. Why do the woman and the child want to kill innocent people when they enter the house? This house sits in the middle of Tokyo as far as I can tell and if this was occurring, there would obviously be a lynch mob there to destroy the house. Later, My next line will explain the lynch mob approach.Somewhere later in the movie the detective explains to Sarah Michelle Geller that there is a curse in Japan where if a violent murder happens in a house, the house is basically haunted.My question is, if that is so, could there be millions of other houses where this has happened? If there were, there would be a tradition in Japan to burn all houses that had violent deaths. The line about that problem should never have been in the script.The problem should have been unique. Another change in the script should have been maybe the woman and child only haunted evil people to their deaths. That's just an opinion if a sequel is ever written.Now back to the discussion that took place on the rooftop between Sarah's character and the detective. When the detective explained what was happening with this house, Sarah's Character should have just said "then we're screwed". By that time we all knew they were. There was no unpredictability in the movie from that time on. I mean at that point couldn't there be some scripting in there where they put everybody's minds together and discussed about finding some unique solution to the haunting problem?That's where the movie fails! It fails bad after that point. Just have godzilla step on the damn house or something! That would have been a much better ending than the way it ended.The only saving grace is that it could be opened to much improved sequels or even a prequel to solve the holes in this movie!rating: terrible, unless you are a kid or something</fullReview>

		<date>2004-10-29</date>
		<username>Warrior_Poet</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Story Factor 5. Creep Factor 10! (Spoilers)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>***No Spoilers Here***Story Factor 5. Creep Factor 10! And that's not a bad thing in this case. In fact, it was rather refreshing.I have a theory why some critics rated 'The Grudge' low, while others have hailed it as the scariest movie of 2004 (of which I am inclined to agree): they were expecting or wanting something more than raw terror, comparing it most likely to the more intricate, thoroughly fleshed-out back-story-driven 'The Ring'. Or, my more promising theory about those who slam it is that they did so to help their ego deal with the urine stains on their pants when they walked out of the theater.Except for the very last scene comprising the last 60 seconds of the movie (which falls a little flat because it's too obvious) and the scene with the thing on the back of her head that was depicted in the previews (which made no sense whatsoever and was unnecessary), this is by far the most intensely eerie movie I've seen, possibly in my lifetime (and I don't state that in an exorbitant, over-exaggerated manner - I really mean it!). Unlike 'The Ring', 'The Grudge' never lets up. There is no downtime. You're in creepsville from beginning to end.'The Ring' was still a better movie with a much more developed plot and fleshed out characters, but it's creep factor pales in comparison to 'The Grudge', which was very well paced (albeit chronologically choppy, which I actually liked), presenting it's menace in a fashion just tangible enough to solidify its supernatural threat into a fear that builds from the very first moments and takes hold without letting up until the very last scene. There is a lot left unexplained, but in this film explanations are irrelevant, and I think that's what some viewers may be missing. They crave to understand, rather than to just trust the filmmaker's vision and feel, severely dampening the overall intended effect.***Spoilers Here***Again, during that last scene the fear factor disperses a bit. It should have either been altered, with just the cops talking about what they'd found, or it should have been removed completely. Either way, having her survive only to have the ghost immediately reappear again was unnecessary and predictable, at which time the fear factor plummets. On the other hand, having the intensity reduced a bit before the credits roll may actually be a blessing.'The Grudge' is also fraught with clichés, primarily using the common horror staple of the lone victim investigating an odd sound only to meet their doom. However, most occurrences of this aren't nearly as far fetched or unbelievable as they usually are in horror films, mainly because at the time the victims are doing the "investigating" they aren't aware that they're being stalked by a supernatural killer until it's too late. In fact, one character, once she realizes the nature of her dilemma and survives, goes through great pains to flee the pursuing menace, running all the way back to her apartment from her office building, even finally cowering in her bed and pulling the cover over her head when finally cornered with no where else to go, essentially giving up and resigning herself to her inevitable fate, also very plausible in my opinion (and leading to yet another very effectively chilling encounter under the bed sheets).***End Spoilers***I recommend this movie only if you're prepared to be looking behind you in mirrors, checking closets, and examining shadows for weeks afterwards. And this is from someone who very rarely finds movies scary. I liked 'The Ring' a lot, but only found it moderately frightening, so if you thought it was scary you might want to avoid this one. Or, wear a Depends undergarment going into it. Bottom line: don't expect sophisticated commentary. This movie was intended to creep you out, and it delivers in spades. It does exactly what its creator wanted it to do, and to rate it by any other measure is folly. Don't go in with preconceived notions trying to think it to death. Just enjoy the ride.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2004-10-28</date>
		<username>Greg (gregmoroberts@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Disappointing</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Here are just some of the reasons why I will never have to worry about the ghost in The Grudge actually causing me some harm or in anyway scaring me to an institutional type state. One: Whenever I hear a noise in a darkened creepy place, I never go to investigate. No way. No how. Hear something banging in the attic? someone else can go look. Hear rumblings in the cellar? you go. I have seen too many movies, read too many books and heard too many stories to put on a brave face and investigate just for the sake of securing my curiosity.Two: My cat never jumps in front of me making a very loud noise while a booming musical score peaks for dramatic effect. My cat is tame and hides from me unless it is hungry. It is not an evil cat. It doesn't snarl and I am sure that if there were evil in the house, the cat would be the first thing to hightail it outta there. My cat pulls a stunt like that one time, and it is off to the shelter where it can terrify another sorry assed stranger.Three: If I ever see something boarded up, it stays boarded up. Who am I to start tearing down something that someone obviously felt necessary to either stop something from getting in or worse, getting out. Hell, if I went home and my bedroom was boarded up, I am sleeping in the kitchen until such time as I can move. End of story.Four: If I ever see police tape around a house, I ain't going' in. Who do you think I am, Agent Mulder? Yellow tapes means something bad has happened and bad begat badder. It means stay out, and I tend to follow instructions rather well.Five: If I ever felt a hand coming out the back of my head in a shower, it is see ya' later bathroom! I wouldn't stop to pack a bag or call a friend. One experience like that and I am out the door never to return again. Whether I ever shower again or not is another story, but you can be assured that I want nothing to do with that particular room again. If I am in a strangers house, it's a 'don't call me, I'll call you' hasty exit. If I am in a foreign country, it is a direct route to the departures lounge and if (and God I hope not) it is in my own home, you are welcome to a viewing as there would be a FOR SALE sign in the front lawn within hours of the incident.With these five simple plans of action listed above, I can't imagine that I would be in the minority, and yet, these situations and character actions occur at random intensity in the off-putting new film The Grudge starring Buffy star Sarah Michelle Gellar. Based on the Japanese film Ju-On The Grudge, the Hollywood edition at least made us stand up and take notice when they announced that director Takashi Shimizu would remake his own film in English. Also interesting was the casting of Gellar not-so-fresh off her long television run as Buffy the Vampire Slayer and in need of a character stretch after playing Daphne in the two gawd-awful Scooby-Doo pics. With Ju-On being a slightly better than average ghost story, the recipe for success was there for the taking.That just makes it all that more unfortunate that the film would fail so miserably. Instead of scaring us or bringing anything new to the table, the movie falls on the laurels of past horror films and gives us a story shot out of sequence (for no reason that I can ascertain) that is more frustrating than thrilling. Gellar looks absolutely lost as the main character, Kare Davis and Bill Pullman has a useless role that was probably offered to him just so they could add another name to the marquee. On the terror meter, The Grudge also has very little to offer. The noises that the ghosts make are almost laughable and the blood and gore content was carefully plotted so that the PG-13 rating could apply.Being October and so close to Halloween, we can expect these types of films to show up in our local playhouses in the next few weeks in hopes of a box office bonanza. Too bad they didn't try to capitalize on a good story as well.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Frightening...if you have ANY intelligence</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>*sigh* the only part of this movie that was laughable was all the awful comments from people trying to prove their intelligence by ripping the movie apart with big words they must have just learned. This movie was GOOD. I'm sorry that because the scenes jumped around many of you were confused, but it wasn't THAT hard to follow. There WAS a plot, and I think people misunderstood many parts. It is when someone dies in a fit of great rage or EXTREME SORROW (just like the officer said to SMG) that it leaves a stain on the place of the event. It curses the place where it happened. I loved the way the movie jumped around, because it leaves you wanting to know more, but also learning what has happened before. It is a technique that Stephan King uses in many of his books. It drives me nuts, but I love it at the same time.Now maybe I'm a wuss, but i was squeezing my boyfriends arm the whole time. I don't like long drawn out gore sessions, but I do enjoy all the waiting for them to happen. The sound the girl made was CREEPY because its a sound that isn't manufactured like that of the video in "The Ring". This movie dealt with average people, and people that died simply because they entered the wrong house. That's what made it so scary. They didn't go looking for the curse, and they weren't bad people. It was innocents dying for no reason.The ending was fitting for this movie. Everybody who has pointed out that they left it open for a sequel.....DUH. You think? This movie is a remake of a movie that ALREADY HAS A SEQUEL. Oi, people...come on.In closing.....this movie was good if you have the intelligence to follow it. It's good if you're going to sit back and enjoy it. It will haunt you afterwards if you have ANY type of imagination. This movie's plot isn't just handed to you, but if you think about it, it will come. 		<username>three_am</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>An excellent Japanese ghost story told for the American audience</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>**CONTAINS SPOILERS** The Grudge is an excellent Japanese story told in American format. I loved the simplicity of the story and the out-of-order sequence in which the story unfolds.Although the plot was thin, which is what some of the reviewers have said, I don't think it needed to be to be spooky. Its simple - vengeful ghosts haunt and torment those that visit their place of death. Its your common "haunted house" story, yet in a way it isn't because it is another culture's interpretation of what it means to step into a haunted house. Despite all the hype of Japanese horror movies, the culture alone has many spooky supernatural tales. The freakiest ghost in the Japanese culture that I ever heard of is the "faceless ghost," who is portrayed as a woman with no face and only has long shiny black hair that disguises the fact that she is faceless. The faceless ghost scares anyone coming upon her into shock. But, I digress from my review of the Grudge.Even though I agree with everyone saying how the thrills and scares were common effects also found in many other horror movies, I thought this movie used it very well in terms of storytelling. I think the most eeriest supernatural stories are the short, mysterious ghost stories like the Vanishing Hitchhiker. The Grudge is like this. The freakiest part of the movie was when the ghost followed the sister Susan to her work building and tormented her there and then followed her home. Anyone who grew up in Hawaii listening to "obake" (ghost) stories will understand why this scene was so "chicken skin"(goosebumps) - its because it reminded me of Hawaii's supernatural tales where the ghosts follow you. I think if you're already a highly superstitious person (like I am) then this movie will genuinely freak and creep you out. I am still left with spooky images of this movie. This is one movie not to miss! I give it 5/5 stars.</fullReview>

		<username>Robert W. (Robert_duder@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Creepy, decent, but mostly forgettable</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I suppose with this film being a remake of a Japanese horror film by Takashi Shimizu, who also did this remake, there will be the inevitable comparisons to "The Ring." Say what you will but The Ring was horrifying, and although the original Ju-On: The Grudge was hailed as the scariest film of all time The Ring (the remake not the Japanese version) was the scariest film I have ever seen hands down and I've seen a lot. The Grudge was excellent. It is the story of a family, a wife and husband and a young boy, who lived in a house in Tokyo. The wife falls completely obsessively in love with an American Professor played briefly by Bill Pullman. The husband discovers his wife's obsession by reading her diary and in an unnatural fit of rage he murders his wife, his son, and their cat before killing himself. According to Japanese folklore when a person dies in a state of rage or deep emotion they leave a curse on the area where they died and it effects everyone who comes into that area. A new family moves into the home, an American businessman, his wife, and his mother. His mother is suffering from old age but the house pushes her into dementia as she barely clings to life being haunted by the dead Japanese wife, and son. The wife begins to torture and eliminate anyone and everyone who sets foot in the house where she was murdered. Sarah Michelle Gellar plays Karen a volunteer caretaker who comes in to look after the elderly woman who has moved into the home. The story is much more complicated than it needs to be and yet at the same time doesn't really ever fully explain clearly what is happening. The scenes of horror creepiness are great and definitely send chills down your spine but they are far apart and are filled with rather slow paced middle story. The movie is almost more of a drama that has moments of scariness. In saying that the scenes of the dead mother and boy are deliciously filmed and are definitely worth a good jump. Sadly Shimizu does at times resort to the "cheap scare" tactics by making you jump in your seat rather than really going for the kind of psychological horror that I had hoped The Grudge would bring. Sarah Michelle Gellar plays the best role I have ever seen her in. She really brings out the acting jibe in this one and granted she hasn't had a lot of opportunity to flex her acting ability but this one did it for her. She played her role perfectly. The Japanese cast including the little boy Toshio played by Yuya Ozeki were brilliant and creepy. Ozeki should have plenty of practise playing this role as this is his third reprisal in the role of Toshio having played him in the original version as well as it's sequel. Point of interest for some the entire Japanese family that plays the evil cursed ghosts are reprising their roles for the third time.I don't think anyone who enjoys a good scary film will be disappointed by The Grudge. It certainly didn't leave me scared to death and I actually felt after leaving the theatre that the film was mostly forgettable which is unfortunate but I hope to see it again as I do believe it will be around a long time as a horror classic.8/10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>CurtMan@LVCM.com</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>I have a Grudge...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>...Against this derivative, frivolous, formulaic, tedious drek in the disguise of "modern horror". There are virtually no edge-of-your seat desirable thrills here, yet there is an irksome pattern of fallacious climaxes delivering to absolutely no avail, rather than a "shocking spook". You'll find cringing in horror, not at the terrifying events on the big screen of course, but rather, at the sheer temerity of a film such as this to appear so promising, and to fail so horribly and cluelessly wrong to thrill or even to entertain. I frequently found myself completely dissociated with the conventions of one naive visitor meandering around the "cursed" estate, devoid of any attention or consideration as to what was to proceed with the characters' hapless fates, as every fate was lamentably predictable, ridiculously formulaic, and instinctively (hilarious). One could not imagine a human being screaming at the top of their lungs at the horrible sight of a stalking spirit possessing an eerie message (errrrrrr) could be laughable, yet the frivolous, derivative (plot stolen from countless recent "horrors" e.g. "The Ring", "Signs", etc.) convention of this scenario is so inextricably lame and gaspingly familiar, that it becomes custom to merely "sigh" or laugh at every doomed character's grisly fate. The film almost saves itself from entirely collapsing towards the very end, with a curious, eerie acquaintance between Sarah Michelle Gellar (Curiosity has certainly killed this cat) and Bill Pullman (whom we have learned has been dead for years by suicide (possibly due to afflictions from "the grudge"), where both of them realize the other's presence, yet proceed silently in their business, Pullman detesting his unfaithful wife, Gellar merely following his hopeless stride. This and the scene where it is revealed that the woman and the boy plaguing the house were gruesomely murdered by the husband and father, are some really ingratiating sequences, and capture some much wanted attention. Yet even these scenes follow the formulaic conventions prevalent throughout the film of being assembled to great promise and interest, yet resulting in some very weak, effort less "climaxes" wherein nothing is resolved, and we can only wait for the cycle to hopelessly repeat itself. What a sorry and inexcusable excuse for a horror built upon chills (which can only be achieved through surprise, which this film completely lacks) and the element of fear (which can only be achieved through careful, unwavering attention to detail and deceiving style, and this film traffics in deviation and guileless transparency). In the end, I really have developed a "grudge" towards this completely wasted execution devoid of any veritable thrill, surprise, shock, or even entertainment; a frighteningly failed attempt at conjuring any horror, that actually evokes guilty gags instead of shocking shrieks... * out of ****</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>If You're Confused Like I Was..Read This (The Grudge)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>If you haven't seen the movie, stop here.So yea, If you're anything like me, then you probably were confused somewhat after seeing this movie. The story was over-stylized and was hard to put together after all was said and done. It wasn't really scary either. Fortunately I figured it out in order. Here Goes...There was once an American college teacher teaching in Japan. Turns out one of his students became obsessed with him. This girl would write about him (and him alone it seems) in her diary. She followed him everywhere she could and she even could be seen in the background of some of his pictures. She would send him tons of letters and he had no clue who it was. So one day he finally decided to follow the return address on the letters and he came upon a simple looking house. In the house was a boy who looked pretty beat up. He decided to stay with the child until his mother (the obsessed girl) returned. While there, the teacher did some exploring and found the girl's diary and some pictures of her and the beat-up boy and another man all over the floor. Her face was torn out of all the pictures. He explored further and found her dead. Because of this, the teacher ended up killing himself the next day. What happened was that this girl was married and had a child. Her husband found her diary and read it. He became very angry, as you can imagine, and proceeded to kill her violently before murdering himself. Here began the curse (The grudge). The rage that the girl's husband had when he died remained in the house after his death and anyone who came in contact with it was doomed. So instead of developing this story, the movie goes on showing everybody who came in contact with the curse dying gruesome deaths (at the hands of the ghosts of these dead people) but does little to help us unravel the story. I hope I helped someone.</fullReview>

The movie tried to be tense and atmospheric simultaneously but it held the suspense for too long in most scenes and after a while, this flick became much ado about nothing. What was the plot? Hmmm, normal people would enter this isolated mansion in Tokyo, get terrorized by the ghosts of a murdered Japanese family, then these demons who would either kill or possess the people that entered the house. These evil spirits would get irritable and even come after you in other places, so better not set foot in that house to begin with, they know where you live and work.About the only thing I liked about this movie was the scenery of Tokyo, as some scenes show great glimpses of this world class city. This movie isn't bad on a Plan 9 level, but it's a waste of time. Don't bother.</fullReview>

		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Scary but very inconsistent (warning: spoilers)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This was better than "The Ring" (both Japanese and American versions) in terms of being genuinely frightening, but the inconsistencies bothered me terribly and significantly detracted from the movie's potential impact. In particular, even though ghosts and other supernatural elements obviously require the audience to suspend its disbelief, that gets harder when there are apparently no limitations as to what the "ghoulies" can do. When they break those rules and become seemingly all powerful, it's the functional equivalent of the shark in "Jaws" abandoning the water to go wander the land and chomp people. SPOILER - SPOILER - SPOILER - SPOILER - SPOILER - SPOILER - SPOILER In particular, this movie is centered establishes itself as your basic haunted house flick. Within the house, there is some consistency in what the ghosts can do -- they appear with images resembling themselves in life, but can distort those images in terrifying ways. On the other hand, they act inconsistently, sometimes attacking those who see them, sometimes just scaring them, and sometimes (such as the encounter between SMG and the little boy) acting just slightly off-kilter. But get them outside the house and their powers actually grow: they can imitate other people's voices and take on their appearance (or even in the case of Bill Pullman, get into his head and cause him to commit suicide). Not only does this fly in the face of any type of logic (why would the ghosts get stronger and more flexible away from their base?), but it raises the disturbing question as to why such all-powerful beings seem to have problems killing particular folks other than to entertain the audience by drawing out the suspense (i.e. if you can cause someone to throw himself off a balcony, it should have been a simple matter to force the sister to throw herself down the stairwell or out of the cab, instead of letting her get home to her apartment.)Anyway, I would still recommend the film just because of the extremely disturbing images and overall tension, but the difference between cheap shocks and true terror always comes down to a work's believability, and this one lost me whenever the ghosts took their campaign to the greater Tokyo area.</fullReview>
