		<shortDescription>Good for what it is...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>First off, I will tell you all that I'm a hardcore horror film fanatic. I've seen hundreds of horror movies all throughout my 21 years on this Earth. I've seen mainstream horror, indi horror, Italian horror, Spanish horror, big budget and no budget horror, OOP (out of print) horror, etc.One must approach a horror film in a different manner than most movies. First ask yourself, what is the main goal of a horror movie?-to scare you -to entertain you -to creep you out -often times to make you laugh -to make you have a good time...A horror movie is like a roller-coaster. You get "on board" pretty much knowing what to expect. You pay a few bucks, take your ride and then toss those memories aside after you get your kicks out of it.Horror films are (for the most part) the roller-coaster ride.Films such as Star Wars, Titanic, Saving Private Ryan, and even Requiem For A Dream are to be viewed in a much different light than the horror film.Those above mentioned films stand out because of numerous things. Whether it's the amazing story and imagination that went into Star Wars, the gritty realistic historically accurate war scenes of Saving Private Ryan, or the powerful and gripping acting in Requiem For A Dream. These types of movies are equivalent to taking a vacation at the Six Flags Theme park or Disneyworld. Horror is the cheap quick thrill/entertainment of the roller-coaster. "Epic" (in their own ways) type films are the entire family vacation to that exspensive theme park. When you leave, you will remember those events for a long time, and there was just so much to do and see. Horror is not that. Horror is......well, horror.That being said, I must say that The Grudge is a great horror film. What makes me take notice to a "good" or "great" horror film are the things that make it stand out. Hollywood seems to have lost the grasp on horror over the last 10 years, spitting out "another teen slasher w/out any smarts".While those "slasher" type horror flicks can be fun, they ultimately leave you disappointed by cardboard stories/characters and instead rely on blood/boobies (that's not a bad thing for some people's opinions).This is what makes the Grudge a great horror flick. The blood/gore is only there for impact on certain scenes. It is there to heighten the intensity and creepiness. There isn't much blood, and only a single gory element (no i won't say what it is)...but that's not the point of THIS type of horror movie. The blood/gore was used tastefully and not overdone, but at the same time, not underdone. The story is also what makes The Grudge a great horror flick. It is a unique spin on the traditional "haunted house" tale that us fat lazy Americans are so used to seeing. "House on Haunted Hill", "The Haunting", "13 Ghosts", etc....catch my drift?What makes this "haunted house" tale so interesting is that it's done in a unique way. People come and go into the house as they please, they aren't "trapped" inside or anything. Some people die, and some people don't. It makes it more realistic because while it IS a haunted house, it only appears as a normal house (I guess that's what the average home in Japan looks like). There's no hokey and stereotypical:cobwebs, creaking doors, mysterious moving objects, etc. in the usual haunted house/ghost story flicks. The entire story is done in a series of short tales, each focusing on a character/group of characters. All the stories tie into each other throughout the film...leaving us sometimes confused. Think of how the different stories in the film, "Pulp Fiction" tie together to tell the entire movie, and that's somewhat the same direction the Grudge is aiming at (although definitely not as detailed/integrated). I like that this makes The Grudge stand out from the "standard" horror film. In fact, I can't recall off the top of my head about another horror film using this same technique. While not a new technique, it does make for a much more interesting film. Horror movies either aim to be scary or just fun. This one aims to be scary. A "fun" horror flick would be along the lines of Cabin Fever (meant to be a fun entertaining ride for the audience, concentrating on that and not on the scares)......and SCARY this is. Although i cannot say in fact what film is "scary" because that is a matter of opinion, but in my opinion...it is scary. I'm not going to have nightmares or anything, but yes, the film is creepy, atmospheric and scary. This is a GOOD THING. If you thought The Ring was scary, I consider this film to outdo the Ring on scares by 2 times at least.I just mentioned how creepy the film is. Why is it creepy? It's creepy because of the atmosphere. The house is pretty much a normal house, and the scares rely on the ghosts. I like that. Most horror movies try to rely on the setting too much for the scares and don't concentrate on the actual "horror goods". This film throws in a couple of really unique and creepy ghosts that certainly do their job, and do it well. So what's bad about this movie? What didn't I like you ask? A few things actually. Some of it doesn't seem to make too much sense plot wise. I also think that the film needs more blood/gore (although it's certainly good without it). I think a disturbingly creepy film like this would use the extra blood/gore in a much more effective way than the typical horror movie. You'll get what i'm talking about when you see the scene with Yoko (after she returns from the house). I think the characters could have been a little bit more interesting. Although this is horror, and horror films tend to have cardboard cutout characters, a big budget and ambitious film like this could have been even more effective with better characters. All in all, this film does what horror films are meant to do. It is scary, creepy, atmospheric, filmed in a unique way, and most importantly...original.Some people say this is "like the Ring"...and I must argue. Both films are remakes of their same titled original Asian films, but that's really the only thing similar. The female ghost in The Grudge sorta looks like "Samara" from The Ring as well, but not like most people make it out to be.Don't let the critics stop you from watching this movie. It's worth the money in my opinion. Just go in knowing it's a horror movie, and not Hollywood's attempt to cash in at this year's Oscars and you'll end up leaving with a smile on your face. 8 out of 10 ratingCLIFF NOTES: This is a horror movie, not an attempt at an "epic" film. It has plot holes, some confusing scenes and somewhat "dry" characters. It does have scares, atmosphere, creepiness, and some unique direction/cinematography. It is a fun movie, one to take your girl to. If you enjoy horror movies, i simply cannot see how you wouldn't like this film. Enjoy.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Slightly scary, but completely generic horror film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Warning: some spoilersSo, first, I should tell you that there is absolutely nothing original about this film. There are a couple scenes where the scare is reminiscent of The Ring (in one scene, a cop is watching a monitor and sees the ghost slide up to the security camera, and she presses her face right against it, but does not actually slide through the TV) and one of the killers is an evil looking woman with long hair in front of her face. However, except for those things, The Ring and The Grudge have nothing in common. But I consider it cheating if that's all the movie has. This movie has no suspense, no plot development, no character development, no real climax, and when you're not being startled (or preparing to be) you're quite bored because all the alternate scenes are of SMG running frantically around Tokyo.In the roughly 90 min movie, there is about 10 min where the film is actually interesting, and all scenes involve Bill Pullman, whose character kicked off the whole chain of events. The flashback that introduced him and showed how he came to be involved with the murdering family is very creepy and fascinating. Anyway, the story and the explanations are stupid. The basic idea is that the woman, who is the mother of the little boy, fell in love with Bill Pullman, and stupidly wrote about it in her diary for her husband to find. He freaks out, yet meticulously cuts her face from dozens of photographs and pins them to the door for her to find, then after she sees his little show, he brutally murders her in front of their son, before drowning the boy, and then hanging himself. Evidently, the mother and son were in such a state of rage that after death they were allowed to haunt the house and kill anyone who entered it.Forgive me if I am being culturally insensitive, but that's a really dumb reason. Even if there was something to that myth, the father was more enraged than the mother and son. Why wasn't HE hanging in the house killing people? There's a bunch of other stupid facets of this story, but it would take too long to type them all out. Just know that this movie might make you jump, and the creepy faces of the woman and her son might freak you out a little when you're trying to sleep, but this is an ultimately forgettable and ridiculous horror movie, doing nothing to give credit to the genre. Here's to hoping that The Saw (which I'm seeing THIS weekend) is much better.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>"The Grudge" follows a young nurse, Karen, (Sarah Michelle Gellar) who lives in Tokyo, Japan, and is sent to work at an old house where an elderly woman is living. Unfortunately, the house has a horrible past and a curse was laid upon it - a curse that is brought upon anyone who dares to step into the house. What would have been a routine job for Karen becomes a nightmare where she must fight against good and evil and try and stop the curse from claiming her.This movie came out at the perfect time- just before Halloween, when most people are looking for a scary movie to watch. This film could've been better if it had used more scare tactics, but "The Grudge" does have some really disturbing scenes that are also effective. I guarantee you will jump at least once throughout the movie, it has some unexpected scares. The only problem people may have with this movie is that it's hard to follow, and the film ends when you wouldn't expect it to. If you pay enough attention though, you should be fine, otherwise if you don't you will be lost. I've only seen a little bit of the Japanese original so I can't really compare and contrast the two, but if you're looking for some good scares, go see "The Grudge". That's when the fun begins or lack thereof.Anyone who has seen Japanese cinema knows horror movies from Japan are heavily into suspense without much special effects. I remember reading some news magazine that was profiling Japanese cinema and one interviewee stated that Japanese cinemas do not have the budget like Hollywood movies to use many special effects. Therefore, they have to use mood, camera angles, and such to create suspense in their movies.Now I like this type of movie making. It reminds me of the classic thriller/horror genre of American cinemas in the 1940's and 1950's. That being said, most of this movie was not scary. Like a typical Japanese movie, the movie dragged on too long in some scenes and there is a reason for this. It makes the audience lull into complacency not expecting anything in particular, which makes the happening of a thrilling event much more scary. But again, there is just too many of these types of scenes.If you like Ringu, you might like this movie but Ringu was much more unique in its premise than your common haunted house theme. One of my friends told me that the Japanese version is slightly better than the American version and had offered to loan me his copy but I don't think I am going to see it. I did not like this movie and I was not scared at all.I would have given this movie one out of ten stars but I like Michelle Gellar so I am willing to give it an extra star.</fullReview>

		<date>2004-10-25</date>
		<username>Jay Vydelingum</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Grudgingly Passable Horror Flick</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>If Sarah Michelle Gellar ever admitted to having some kind of pact with the devil, I wouldn't be surprised.After slaying the living dead in 'Buffy', playing tortuous eye-candy in 'Scream 2' and 'I Know What You Did Last Summer', even unmasking ghosts in 'Scooby Doo' it seems she's happiest when there's something creepy in the air.'The Grudge' is a remake of a cult Japanese horror flick 'Ju-on-The Grudge', and sees Gellar as 'Karen', an American student living in Tokyo.Karen helps out at a care home, and when a colleague of hers fails to show for work one day, she is dispatched to a scary house in the hills to look after a woman. It soon transpires that all is not well within those four walls, as the house harbours a violent secret.Director Takashi Shimizu's first foray into dealing with Hollywood is an admirable one, although there is a worrying familiarity with other recent US reworkings of Asian cinema, notably 'The Ring'. However, where that version succeeds due to the specific channelling of the evil, (ie, a videotape),'The Grudge' falls down due to the vague manner in which the spell manifests itself.That's not to say there are no redeeming features. 'The Grudge' has strong suspense and heart-stopping shocks throughout, but often there's a sense that they are contrived plot devices which contribute little towards the complete story.Gellar acquits herself as the frightened Westerner trying to unlock the origins of the curse, but it is young Yuya Ozeki who deserves a special mention for his sinister performance as 'Toshio'.A little derivative at times, 'The Grudge' nonetheless has numerous scary moments horror lovers will devour, but fans of the original should probably approach with caution. (6/10)</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2004-10-24</date>
		<username>tabuno</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Excellent Execution, Flawed Ending</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The cinematographic and directorial technique were great in this movie, but the ending was a pretty miserable failure...unable to really provide the audience with any satisfying new twist on the hundreds of horror movies that have come before. The avoidance of the gory and literally, ghastly onslaught of over the top scenes and sights was a nice touch. This more subtle, sedate, but always ominous mystery builds throughout the movie with nice flashbacks and a great scene of juxtapositions between past and present that rates with any horror movie. The sound effects, the musical background (with some familiar strains from "Wait Until Dark" were effective. This movie wasn't scary in the classic sense, the emotional dread was more saturated like a wet, humid, cloying feeling. Not all of the strands of the movie were tied up by the end, there were lingering questions, and the climax was more of huge letdown. Seven out of Ten Stars (for good directing, but lost potential for a spectacular, memorable hit).</fullReview>
	</review>

Not a great movie, but worth seeing.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>Now I have seen the original and feel the first 45 minutes of the original are up there with some of the best directing of any horror movie ever made. The tension building is ingenious, leaving little details to be figured out by the viewer, but sadly the movie falls into satirical mediocrity soon after. I still rated the movie a 7 overall.The remake I went into knowing they would really speed things along and anything I loved from the original would be different and that's okay, it's to be expected, but this movie simply failed at building tension, and failed at being even remotely scary.It's like they spent all their energy trying rather then doing that it completely misses the mark.For remakes of Japanese movies, The Ring was exceptional but it had all the right people directing, doing effects, casted, etc.. it all just worked, and I am in love with the entire original Japanese series of Ring,particularly Yukie Nakama in Ring 0.Anyways, this was a rather mediocre film, definitely a failed remake. I dread them remaking A Tale of Two Sisters, the original is a masterpiece.All the CGI in this movie made it feel unreal, and more like Casper the ghost then an intensely powerful grudge stalking a house.From this movie I get this impression they tried TOO hard to Americanize it and in doing so sort of disrespected the culture involved. I wish more people would watch original Asian cinema, The Ring series, Uzumaki, A Tale of Two Sisters, Some movies simply should not be remade, because you're changing elements, elements that changed can really throw off all the chemistry to a story, turning it into a mockery of the original folklore.I am not saying I'm against cross culturization, but come on, if you want to bring the cultures together, make a NEW story about an American in Japan not constantly doing remakes.Sometimes remakes are good because they introduce us to the original films we may never have seen otherwise, but it's all in the way it's formulated. And the Grudge originally was a bit silly, but the remake lacked any of the original's tension and only held to the silliness. Every time the Grudge builds it falls flat and leaves me disappointed.In the original, we see near the beginning the woman cleaning the house then she takes a nap. A eerie gust of wind comes along and blows her things over in complete disarray, silently we understand why the house is so messy and why they don't even bother cleaning, it's because the Grudge destroys any semblance of organization once established. Sadly this movie doesn't confront such fascinating details in as intelligently a fashion.Things jump out at you but in the theaters no one screamed, they laughed,because the timing was wrong, just wasn't scary.The Grudge simply doesn't deliver. I say save your money, watch the original Ring series, watch A Tale of Two Sisters, watch Battle Royale, watch Inner Senses, watch The Eye... avoid The Grudge.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2004-10-23</date>
		<username>w00f</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>A Decent Halloween Haunted House Flick</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Not great (I think The Ring was light years beyond this one on my personal fearometer), but I'd recommend it as a fun Halloween flick that's perfect for those who can't shell out the $50+ entrance fee for an amusement park spooking.For the most part, The Grudge is an old-fashioned haunted house movie. What's new here is mainly that ghosts are portrayed in pretty high-tech ways these days, but this is definitely a "things that go bump in the night" story. It's fright value lies mostly in the technique of the unexpected hand on the shoulder. It startles more often than it scares.Sara Michelle Gellar is OK in her role as the main character. I doubt this role stretched her acting abilities much; all she really had to do was act scared every so often, and was called upon to be largely deadpan between. Her character is mainly a lightning rod for spooky things to happen as the movie moves along. I should say, too, that the movie moves backwards and forwards along the plot line in various ways, and it sometimes comes off a bit choppy because of this. Bill Pullman has a small role; he starts off the story by jumping to his death off a sixth story apartment balcony, and the rest of the film unravels the reason why he's done this.The ghosts themselves are pretty effective. The effects people did a great job of combining some truly ghoulish makeup and some choice sound effects. The ghosts are, of course, the true stars of this movie, and everyone else is more or less window-dressing.All in all, I think this movie will scare people who haven't seen a lot of horror flicks more than it will those of us who have seen so many that they've lost count. Not that there isn't something to be had by jaded horror fans such as myself, too, but I suspect that most of us who have seen this kind of thing before can see the scares coming. The startling bits aren't that startling if you already know what's about to happen. People who haven't seen a lot of movies in this genre, however, are likely to loose a scream or two, as did the audience members in the theater where I saw the movie.And please, somebody buy Toshio a new scratching post and some catnip. It'd make him very happy. Thanks.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Maybe if it had been rated R...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>There's a 30 to 45-minute movie buried in THE GRUDGE that would've been perfectly decent fright fare. A house, where awful things happened to the original owners, has awful things happen to anyone else who enters. Like THE RING, in a way, except instead of a videotape you watch, then die, there's this big house you set foot in, and then die. And, it doesn't take a week. A half hour of this would do; at feature length, it takes its toll. A character hears a noise off-screen, then slowly, cautiously walks toward it, the soundtrack building to crescendo, weird sh*t happens to them, fade to black. Repeat. Surely, it wasn't necessary to see this more than once or twice. But, alas. I think Sarah Michelle Gellar is ridiculously cute. I'd love to see her in something darker, with more of an edge. Stephen Susco's script, here, doesn't have her doing a whole whole lot, so most of her acting's got to be in the eyes. Unfortunately, all we get is a look of innocence, or a look of consternation. Lazy performance. And, the film is too mild-mannered for its own good, anyway. There are scares -- one in particular, with Gellar taking a bus home, reminded me I had a pulse -- only few, and far between. Anyone who can explain why the ghost kills certain people, while only scaring others into catatonia, wins a prize.</fullReview>

The beauty of this film is that it is based in Tokyo and not in the United States. Just seeing the main character, brilliantly played by Sarah Michelle Gellar dealing with the cultural changes and the over whelming aura of the city of Tokyo is very satisfying. The film is paced perfectly and just when you let your guard down for a second you are sent screaming out of your seat leaving you with sharp tingles running down your spine. A lot of people will be comparing this film to The Ring, which in it's own right is a great movie, but it's not even on the same page as The Grudge. I was so impressed with Sarah Michelle Gellar, she blended in so well with the intriguing story and never tried to look like the pretty sorority girl that we have come so accustom to. Don't get me wrong I do love that look, but it would not work in this flick. Overall, I highly recommend this movie to everyone, but I would not go alone as you will probably be looking over your shoulder for the full hour and a half.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>...you can never forget</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>OK people gather 'round. i'm about to tell you a tale of misery and woh...The Grudge trailers are lying to you! it's not as cool as it looks! before you waste your well earned money on this "movie", take this into consideration...if you have seen the ring,gothika,any freddy crougar movie, or any movie about the walking dead, then you've seen the grudge. This movie borrows every memorable scene, plot line, or moment from each of these movies. If you take out the word "tape" in 'the ring' and replace it with "the house", and put an actual person on the other end of the phone call, then you've got the grudge. Seriously, every time someone picked up the phone i swear i expected a small, wet, dead girl to respond "7 days....". Also, one scene in The Grudge bears a striking resemblance to Gothika. The first woman killed, Yoko, is somehow up and walking around again...very slowly...and very dead...not hearing the man calling her name. The walk is identical to that of the girl in Gothika. And in case i haven't convinced you yet, Karen(sarah michelle gellar) is in her apartment or something when "the grudge" (or whatever you want to call the little spirit girl there) comes to get her. Being the stereotypical horror scene that it is, Karen runs like a scared little girl into her bed, and pulls the sheets over her. At this point, all the young, annoying girls in the theatre are screaming because something is moving slowly up Karen's bed (under the sheets, of course). Karen lifts the sheets and...BY GOD! I THINK THAT'S THE LITTLE SPIRIT GIRL! Now how did she do that? Well, Karen sees the little spirit girl and then everyone's screaming and there's that annoying high-pitched horror movie sound going on, and Karen just kinda disappears into the bed. Needless to say, Freddy. The Grudge may have been better if, i don't know, THEY GAVE YOU MORE INFORMATION BEFORE IT ALL GETS SUMMED UP IN 10 SECONDS IN A RANDOM VISION BY THE MAIN Character. Seriously, it's not a good movie when the entire background information gets shown in a random 10-15 second black and white vision, that karen isn't even in(and might i add she's the one having said vision), all to the tune of a random corpse just kinda...hanging there, and banging against the wall. Oh, and before she goes into the banging corpse room, it's making an ever-louder 'thud'. Jurassic park? I think so. All they needed was the glass of water. Or better yet they should have had the Kool-Aid guy burst in with his trademark "OHH YEAH!". Anything to make the scared little kids stop screaming at the visuals, which i will admit, were creepy at times, and creepy at best. Cheap tricks. Makes you jump, you know?I had high hopes for this film. Very high. Sadly though, my hopes were brutally murdered like the stereotypical Japanese horror film characters in it. And they always seem to have the need to look for the source of this 'bang' or that 'thud'. And they die. Well, that's what you get, stupid.Overall: *.5/*****</fullReview>

		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>An incredibly creepy and nightmare-inducing version of "Lost in Translation"</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I had one of the best times I've ever had at the movies last night watching "The Grudge." I wouldn't say it was brilliant film. The low-budget look and PG-13 rating combined with the fact that the audience was filled with teenagers definitely contributed to an overall B-Movie vibe. But, DAMN, was this movie scary! Even though it's not as high-budget as "The Ring," or as densely plotted, it compares favorably (if you're one of those retarded Americans who HAS to compare one Japanese horror-inspired remake to another). What "The Grudge" has going on in its favor is an unmistakable and potent aura of creepiness and unpleasantness underscoring some of the most intensely orchestrated shocks in recent memory. I saw it in a packed house and I can't even begin to describe the screaming, gasping, and shrieking that went on around me. It's been a long time since I've seen an exceedingly well-crafted and skillfully made horror film. This one definitely comes VERY close to being just that.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>Not great (I think The Ring was light years beyond this one on my personal fearometer), but I'd recommend it as a fun Halloween flick that's perfect for those who can't shell out the $50+ entrance fee for an amusement park spooking.For the most part, The Grudge is an old-fashioned haunted house movie. What's new here is mainly that ghosts are portrayed in pretty high-tech ways these days, but this is definitely a "things that go bump in the night" story. It's fright value lies mostly in the technique of the unexpected hand on the shoulder. It startles more often than it scares.Sara Michelle Gellar is OK in her role as the main character. I doubt this role stretched her acting abilities much; all she really had to do was act scared every so often, and was called upon to be largely deadpan between. Her character is mainly a lightning rod for spooky things to happen as the movie moves along. I should say, too, that the movie moves backwards and forwards along the plot line in various ways, and it sometimes comes off a bit choppy because of this. Bill Pullman has a small role; he starts off the story by jumping to his death off a sixth story apartment balcony, and the rest of the film unravels the reason why he's done this.The ghosts themselves are pretty effective. The effects people did a great job of combining some truly ghoulish makeup and some choice sound effects. The ghosts are, of course, the true stars of this movie, and everyone else is more or less window-dressing.All in all, I think this movie will scare people who haven't seen a lot of horror flicks more than it will those of us who have seen so many that they've lost count. Not that there isn't something to be had by jaded horror fans such as myself, too, but I suspect that most of us who have seen this kind of thing before can see the scares coming. The startling bits aren't that startling if you already know what's about to happen. People who haven't seen a lot of movies in this genre, however, are likely to loose a scream or two, as did the audience members in the theater where I saw the movie.And please, somebody buy Toshio a new scratching post and some catnip. It'd make him very happy. Thanks.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Maybe if it had been rated R...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>There's a 30 to 45-minute movie buried in THE GRUDGE that would've been perfectly decent fright fare. A house, where awful things happened to the original owners, has awful things happen to anyone else who enters. Like THE RING, in a way, except instead of a videotape you watch, then die, there's this big house you set foot in, and then die. And, it doesn't take a week. A half hour of this would do; at feature length, it takes its toll. A character hears a noise off-screen, then slowly, cautiously walks toward it, the soundtrack building to crescendo, weird sh*t happens to them, fade to black. Repeat. Surely, it wasn't necessary to see this more than once or twice. But, alas. I think Sarah Michelle Gellar is ridiculously cute. I'd love to see her in something darker, with more of an edge. Stephen Susco's script, here, doesn't have her doing a whole whole lot, so most of her acting's got to be in the eyes. Unfortunately, all we get is a look of innocence, or a look of consternation. Lazy performance. And, the film is too mild-mannered for its own good, anyway. There are scares -- one in particular, with Gellar taking a bus home, reminded me I had a pulse -- only few, and far between. Anyone who can explain why the ghost kills certain people, while only scaring others into catatonia, wins a prize.</fullReview>

This movie borrows every memorable scene, plot line, or moment from each of these movies. If you take out the word "tape" in 'the ring' and replace it with "the house", and put an actual person on the other end of the phone call, then you've got the grudge. Seriously, every time someone picked up the phone i swear i expected a small, wet, dead girl to respond "7 days....". Also, one scene in The Grudge bears a striking resemblance to Gothika. The first woman killed, Yoko, is somehow up and walking around again...very slowly...and very dead...not hearing the man calling her name. The walk is identical to that of the girl in Gothika. And in case i haven't convinced you yet, Karen(sarah michelle gellar) is in her apartment or something when "the grudge" (or whatever you want to call the little spirit girl there) comes to get her. Being the stereotypical horror scene that it is, Karen runs like a scared little girl into her bed, and pulls the sheets over her. At this point, all the young, annoying girls in the theatre are screaming because something is moving slowly up Karen's bed (under the sheets, of course). Karen lifts the sheets and...BY GOD! I THINK THAT'S THE LITTLE SPIRIT GIRL! Now how did she do that? Well, Karen sees the little spirit girl and then everyone's screaming and there's that annoying high-pitched horror movie sound going on, and Karen just kinda disappears into the bed. Needless to say, Freddy. The Grudge may have been better if, i don't know, THEY GAVE YOU MORE INFORMATION BEFORE IT ALL GETS SUMMED UP IN 10 SECONDS IN A RANDOM VISION BY THE MAIN Character. Seriously, it's not a good movie when the entire background information gets shown in a random 10-15 second black and white vision, that karen isn't even in(and might i add she's the one having said vision), all to the tune of a random corpse just kinda...hanging there, and banging against the wall. Oh, and before she goes into the banging corpse room, it's making an ever-louder 'thud'. Jurassic park? I think so. All they needed was the glass of water. Or better yet they should have had the Kool-Aid guy burst in with his trademark "OHH YEAH!". Anything to make the scared little kids stop screaming at the visuals, which i will admit, were creepy at times, and creepy at best. Cheap tricks. Makes you jump, you know?I had high hopes for this film. Very high. Sadly though, my hopes were brutally murdered like the stereotypical Japanese horror film characters in it. And they always seem to have the need to look for the source of this 'bang' or that 'thud'. And they die. Well, that's what you get, stupid.Overall: *.5/*****</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>An incredibly creepy and nightmare-inducing version of "Lost in Translation"</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I had one of the best times I've ever had at the movies last night watching "The Grudge." I wouldn't say it was brilliant film. The low-budget look and PG-13 rating combined with the fact that the audience was filled with teenagers definitely contributed to an overall B-Movie vibe. But, DAMN, was this movie scary! Even though it's not as high-budget as "The Ring," or as densely plotted, it compares favorably (if you're one of those retarded Americans who HAS to compare one Japanese horror-inspired remake to another). What "The Grudge" has going on in its favor is an unmistakable and potent aura of creepiness and unpleasantness underscoring some of the most intensely orchestrated shocks in recent memory. I saw it in a packed house and I can't even begin to describe the screaming, gasping, and shrieking that went on around me. It's been a long time since I've seen an exceedingly well-crafted and skillfully made horror film. This one definitely comes VERY close to being just that.</fullReview>

		<username>brennan79</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>It Never Forgets And Neither Will You (VERY MINOR SPOILERS)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I went to see The Grudge with three of my friends. Even though I am a long (long, long, long) time die-hard horror film aficionado, I (for the first time ever) found the movie so frightening, I was almost in tears. While my best friend agreed with me, the two other friends with us did not find it particularly scary at all. I was shocked to hear them say this until I realized what was going on. Those two friends had seen the 2004 remake of "Texas Chainsaw Massacre" and left the theater in a similar state to the one I was in after "The Grudge". While I found "TCM" to be an excellent and devoted re-visioning, it did not scare me in the least...just like the original version was an excellent film but not frightening (in my opinion).Those two friends are terrified by "real life" (i.e. nothing supernatural) blood and gore films. That sub-genre of horror is everything "The Grudge" is not. Instead, "The Grudge" represents everything that has frightened me and haunted my imagination since I was a child. It is an unrelenting barrage of humans who open their mouths to release completely inhuman sounds (that literally make the hairs on the back of your neck stand on end), people walking down dark hallways with a lurching limp or with their heads rolled impossibly far to one side, children who appear sweet and innocent only to look subtly inhuman and undeniably demonic upon closer view, things that are not under the bed but already in the bed waiting for you, evil that will unquestionably win in the end...it's only a matter of how much Hell you are willing to put yourself through until that defeat occurs. What makes these things (and the film as a whole) so terrifying to me is that in all of these figments of the darker recesses of imagination lies the inherent realization that they are not so completely far-fetched that they could never actually happen. They are all ordinary things that take on a sinister new personality by simply enhancing or omitting a single characteristic of the norm. This is made all the better by the tradition of Japanese filmmakers to leave it up to the audience to decide the full reasons behind the events rather than spell everything out for us...a practice not forgotten in this remake. If this type of Twilight Zone-ish horror is your cup of tea, then you will leave this film feeling as though you may never sleep with both eyes shut again. When on of the victims slowly turns around to reveal a greatly contorted mouth missing the lower jaw, I felt the need to look behind me to make sure she wasn't occupying any nearby theater seats. That is something that never crossed my mind during "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre". 10/10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>The Drudge</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>SPOILER ALERTBefore beginning I'll admit that I did not want to see this film but was dragged to it so I myself had a grudge against it and thus am not totally impartial on seeing it. Still, I should have guessed from the previews and word of mouth that this was going to suck.The story does not make any sense in that those who enter the house die. If this is true, what about the real estate guy? The detective's assistant and the other cops there doing forensic evidence? Also I had a problem with the fact that NOBODY TURNS ON THE LIGHTS! Although I have not yet seen feardotcom (which is supposed to be god-awful) from what I have heard this film parallels it in that these characters also neglect to turn on the lights.But these are minor: the main problems are the story and editing. It was very confusing with the rapid cuts and jumping around of narrative - I understood everything that happened at the end, but I had to do too much piecework to make it make sense, and there are still huge loopholes. Worse, this really detracts from the characters in that you don't care about them since we see them so briefly and then they appear quickly and die - they just seemed like fodder for the house and didn't really have any personal life, goals, meaningful relationships, etc. And if you're going to have a haunted house, make it look scary not sterile and cold and boring like this one.This may also explain why I couldn't find it scary because the cuts happened so often that you didn't a chance to buildup the anticipation - not to mention the transitions themselves (i.e. constant dips to black at the end of every scene) were overused and at strange points. To top it off, the film goes through a checklist of horror clichés (girl in shower, people sticking parts into dangerous places despite knowing something is wrong, hearing scary noises and heading towards them are just a few). Lastly the overused sound "jumps" where a scary noise is put in was distracting and the kid who meows like a cat was just plain hilarious though I don't think this was the intent. And for the ending, well, if you couldn't see that coming (or any of the "scares") a mile away I have some swampland in Florida I'd like to sell you.There were some good things about it in that the sound and music edits were great and so was the lighting (when it chose to make a cameo). The acting wasn't bad but the script didn't require much more than delivering lines or breathing hard to indicate fear. Also, the remake/adaptation doesn't much matter it took place in Japan and seems like a lot more could have been done. And why did nobody else in the area know of the multiple deaths in the house? Don't try to make sense of this movie, in fact, ignore it altogether and rent something else.FINAL VERDICT: IGNORE */***** (1/5)</fullReview>
	</review>

However it goes on to the trite ending of her boyfriend is dead; she tried to, but didn't succeed, to burn the house down and then the hackneyed "morgue" scene where you see that she is still haunted by the ghost. YAWN!!!!! The funniest part of the movie was where Yoko comes back from the dead, ( Yoko is the first nurse hired by the Williams family to take care of their sick mother) and she's jerking through the hospital where she use to work (like something from Michael Jackson's Thriller) and her boss comes across her and keeps calling to her. As she turned around, someone from the audience shouted, "Yoko! OH NO!" totally busting up the audience and thankfully spoiling the scare scene. This movie relies on its special effects, because it has no plot. The only redeeming quality was you get to see some of Tokyo. DO NOT see this movie, or at least go to one of those multi-plex theaters and go see another good movie and then afterwards sneak into this move to see how bad it actually is.</fullReview>

		<date>2004-10-22</date>
		<username>Rack-Focus</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>THE SIXTH SENSE MEETS LOST IN TRANSLATION</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>THE GUDGE is a decent horror flick that could have been better without the split personality. It's based on the Japanese film Ju-on: The Grudge (2003). In the American version, the filmmakers apparently took the easy way out and stapled Lost in Translation (2003) to the front of the script.PART 1: LOST IN TRANSLATION: As a result, the first third of the movie mirrors Lost in Translation's frozen inaction and snail's pace. It's so boring I almost walked out and serves no purpose except to awkwardly splice Caucasians into an Asian movie.These elements also kill plot development. Dialogue is minimized because much of the early talking is subtitled Japanese. As a result we learn very little about the characters and develop few feelings for them. Most are bland anyway. One is an even accountant! The location is similarly wasted. Any local color that could explain why the movie should take place in Japan is abandoned in favor of generic city shots.PART II: SIXTH SENSE: But once The Grudge shifts in The Sixth Sense (1999) mode, things improve rapidly. The movie mimics the Sixth Sense's style of shadows and quick cuts of the horror to keep us scared and guessing when the next fright will strike. And the movie does deliver the chills.So if you're willing to put up with a very slow start, The Grudge will take you to a fine frightful finish.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Not a good crossbreed of Japanese and American films</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I like a lot of the neo-Japanese films because they dare to push the envelope. Take films like "Audition" (makes "Fatal Attraction" look sloppy) or even "Zatoichi" (which mix the ancient with the new). But there are neo-Japanese films that become redundant, like "Tomie". So when I heard "The Grudge", which was based on the Japanese film of the similar name, was coming out and it was directed by the same director of the Japanese film, I was definitely intrigued.Just came from the film, and it pretty much sucked. Yeah, sucked. Though I liked the photography (by Hideo Yamamoto of "Ichi the Killer" and "Audition") and the fact that Ryo Ishibashi, the main actor from "Audition", was in it, the rest of this movie just falls more into the American schlock-shock fest. Though the concept had great potential, we kind of get the idea from the 1st 30 minutes what is going on. On top of this, put in the usual scary faces, violin shrieks, and the little gremlin who meows creepy, and you got your general teen shock flick. Sarah Michelle Gellar really does not add much to the film, not to mention that her and her fiancée's part were really unnecessary in the film. This could have been explored more from the Japanese detective's point of view (no, this is not a spoiler). I really cannot recommend this film unless you're easily scared. Half the theatre was laughing (kind of like "Exorcist IV"). The movie had potential to be a good crossbreed of Neo-Japanese and American film, but failed miserably secondary to the greater emphasis on cheap American scare tactics and less development/innovation on the Japanese part. Even more disappointing is the fact that Sam Raimi, the great "Evil Dead" I and II director, actually produced this garbage.4/10</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>The Grudge Report</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I know I'm going to p*** a couple of people off with my review but hey, these are the breaks. I consider myself a fan and supporter of Asian horror movies. Ringu, The Eye, Ju-On, I love them all. I am also one of those people that has gotten a little annoyed with the remake happy system that Hollywood has adopted as of late but at the same time, I'd be lying if I told you that I hated the American remake of the Ring. In fact, I consider the Ring to be one of the best horror movies to come out of the system in a while and I also think it's just as good,if not better, than the original. Which brings me to the remake of Ju-On: The Grudge. I saw it last night at a midnight sneak preview and I'm writing this review on three and a half hours of sleep so cut me some slack. I saw the original a few months ago on DVD and I was pretty unnerved while watching it but at the same time I felt that it became a little confusing, especially near the end.Right off the bat, I'd say that the remake is much better than the original. In fact, I would stand up and yell it out right now if I didn't mind getting fired afterwards. I found the movie to be well made with better production values, better special effects and really just downright scarier. I love the idea of getting the original director to do his own remake. That, to me, shows respect for the source of the film. I've seen remakes and adaptations of movies where the only similarity to the original source was in the name and that's it. I think this strategy of hiring the original director is a step in the right direction. I also dig the fact that they filmed it in Japan as well. While there were slight changes made from the original in terms of story, they weren't anything for the purists to freak out about. In all honesty, I found that the changes to the story made it easier to follow. The plot is basically the same with some details added and some of the subplots left out. The storyline is still told in a nonlinear fashion and keeps you guessing until the very end but everything ties together pretty nicely. The acting was better than I expected and I was especially happy to see Bill Pullman in the movie, though his role is small. Sarah Michelle Gellar looked just as freaked out here as she did in Scream 2 but I thought she gave a decent performance. In terms of scares, I have to say that this movie kept me feeling uncomfortable the entire time I was watching it. Even though there were some scenes where I knew exactly what to expect, they changed it around enough to make it fresh. Even the scenes that were a direct lift off of the original were done much better, with some of the practical effects enhanced by CGI. I didn't really have any issues with the movie, although I was disappointed that one or two of the scenes from the original didn't make it into the remake in some form. I really enjoyed watching this movie and I think anyone with even the slightest appreciation for Asian horror films and horror films in general will like this movie. The crowd I was with loved it also. As far as remakes go, I would say this comes in just behind the Ring. Even though the Ring had far less shock scares, I just found that particular movie to be more frightening for some reason.RATING: ***1/2 out of *****</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Not a first</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>IMDb reported erroneously that "The Grudge" is the first foreign-language film to be remade by in English by its original filmmaker. Not true. France's Francis Veber made "Les Fugitfs" with Gerard Depardieu and Pierre Richard in 1986 and then went to Hollywood in 1989 to remake it in Engoish with Nick Nolte and Martin Short. Just a bit of trivia for you. As for the remake of "The Grudge," it is about a curse that leaves one who dies in the grip of a powerful rage, based by Takashi Shimizu on his "Ju-On." Those who encounter this murderous supernatural curse die and a new one is born, passe like a virus in an endless, growing chain of horror. It's virtually the same movie, kind of like what Gus Van Sant did with 'Psycho' a few years ago, only this new version stars Sarah Michelle Geller. 'The Grudge' is essentially just a haunted house movie, one involving a black cat, a kid who could be dead and a whirl of dark smoke in the form of a human, replete with mascara-lined eyes. This material tries to camouflage its nagging repetitiveness with a lot of confusing flashbacks. The one novel touch that Shimizu repeats here is that he keeps everything light and airy, not dark and dreary. Reviewing 'Ju-On,' I wondered how Shimizu could possibly remake it for American audiences, given that so much of the material seemed to be wrapped up in the Japanese culture. The filmmaker avoided that problem by simply not relocating his remake, keeping it in Japan and populating with mostly Asian actors. He uses Geller and the other few Caucasian actors here ? most notably Bill Pullman, Clea Duvall and Grace Zabriskie ? in a dramatically valid way as displaced people who are even more confounded by the bizarre terrors here than the locals are.</fullReview>
	</review>

'The Grudge' posits that anyone who enters the doors becomes cursed by the fury that inhabits the home -- a curse happy to follow you back to your house, work, elevator, car. While there are a few campy conventions -- is anyone really going to venture into an attic oozing with the sounds of thuds and moans with only a lighter to illuminate the way? -- the film, for the most part, works like a charm. 		<date>2005-09-10</date>
		<username>LimeyDave</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>The Ring for those with a brain</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Having started with the inevitable comparison in the title, I'll side-step the whole "Ring vs Grudge" argument for later. The Grudge is actually a remake of a Japanese film Ju-on: the Grudge aka Ju-on 3, the third, (obviously), in a series of movies.It's impossible to tell you the storyline, without giving away some of the "surprises" in the plot, so go ahead and skip to the next paragraph if you don't want to spoil those surprises. The basic story, set in Japan, is that of an American family taking up residence in a house whose previous occupants had been involved in domestic murder/suicide. Enter Sarah Michelle Geller as the new American care worker for the disabled mother, (the first care worker having been dispatched in one of the opening scenes) and all manner of spooky goings on ensue. It seems that anyone entering the house, is subject to "The Grudge" or curse that now haunts the house, and after a short period of time is visited by an apparition which.... well you don't actually see what it does, but you know its just not pleasant.To judge The Grudge is not that easy, it's rather non-liner style does mean that the viewer has to carefully pay attention to the movie as the story unfolds. Unlike The Ring, (which I thought was pretty excellent), which washed over and enveloped you into the storyline, The Grudge is far more subtle in it's scares. For example, when one of the characters is in an elevator, going to the top of her building, if you don't pay attention to what's going on in the background, the scene just looks like a woman in an elevator. Nothing scary there, right? But by paying attention, the viewer is left with an impending sense of dread, as the character alights the elevator, and enters her apartment, oblivious to her fate. It is subtlety such as this, that will escape anyone who thought Friday the 13th was a demanding experience, and leave them a bit cold. This is NOT an in your face movie.It's ironic that perhaps The Grudge's biggest strengths, could also be regarded as some of its biggest weakness'. The film is shot in such a way as to make the viewer is a rather dispassionate voyeur on the unfolding events. This approach is good, in that we get to see all parts of the story, and are able to piece things together in a way the characters cannot. However, it can leave the viewer feeling a little uninvolved also. Too, as mentioned in the storyline paragraph, all the actual killings occur off camera. Wonderful for those of us with an imagination, not so good for the "if it don't splatter, it don't matter" brigade.The Japanese certainly have their own style of movie making, and Takashi Shimizu who directs, (I believe this is his first film for western audiences), thankfully does not compromise that style too much. The time line jumps, are used to explain events after we have seen them, and rather than the usual "creepy" music, a soul chilling sound is used to build tension, and let us the viewer know of an imminent attack by the apparition. This certainly will not to be everyone's taste, but then I like my movies to confuse me, then give me a chance to work things out, rather than spell them out to me one syllable at a time.I started this off side-stepping the whole "Ring vs Grudge" debate, and will address that now. Let's start this off by looking at what they have in common. Both were based on Japanese films, (Ringu for The Ring and Ju-on: The Grudge aka Ju-on 3 for The Grudge). Both have apparitions with lots of hair. Both have creepy kids in them, and and both are ghost stories. Its there that the direct comparisons really end. To have seen one is definitely not to have seen the other. Was one "inspired" (read ripped off), by the other, quite possibly, but who cares? Tarantino has been making movies "inspired" by other movies for years, and we love him for it.The performances by the actors are adequate, nothing Oscar winning, but certainly good enough to keep things believable.To summarize. The Grudge is a good little movie, to be watched when one can give it ones full attention, and at night with the lights low and someone special to cling to for the scary bits. Watching it with distractions, (kids going to bed, won't go to bed, friends visiting and insisting on talking all the way through the movie, etc.), is NOT going to work.Overall, a good ghost story, and well worth the watch.</fullReview>

		<username>pressboard</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Buffy meets Kubuki</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The review by Togasaurus I think describes this movies structure and intent best. Americans look for ghosts (spirits) who have a reason for being, an intent, a location and a resolution. On the other hand, the Japanese believe in a more basic animism. The spirit is independent of the person who died and exists as the embodiment of an emotion - in this case rage. The spirits and the atmosphere in which they are revealed is done excellently - but there is no motivation or resolution. They are rage. They are not limited to a location, but can manifest anywhere where the victims happen to be. Supposedly, they pass their rage on to their victims. Their victims then die and new rage spirits are born. The spirits, at least in this movie, are not banished or exorcised. They continue to exist and continue to kill. Most of this is not communicated in The Grudge. You either know the culture or you do not. From what I was reading I guess this rage was passed on to most Americans who saw this movie. Watching The Grudge I felt like I was on the verge of really liking this movie, but was lacking the necessary understanding to do so - a strange feeling. Anyway, this is worth a watch on cable or DVD.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>Whenever somebody dies in the grip of a terrible rage a curse is begun that consumes all that come into contact with it. At some point something has happened in an old house in the suburbs of Tokyo, although nobody would have guessed that this is what has happened to medical student Yoko, who has just gone missing. Her replacement is American Karen Davis, who is sent out to cover for Yoko and look after the old woman who is bedridden and needs looking after. Very quickly though, Karen begins to notice that not all is as it should be.Japanese horror is certainly different and the focus on atmosphere and chills rather than jump shocks are two of the things that have made things like Ringu and Honogurai Mizuno Sokokara really creep me out and stick in my mind every bloody time I have to turn the lights out and walk across a dark room to the door. However, with so many average films using the formula without adding anything and American version remaking the original in a shot-for-shot way that is like an expensive form of dubbing then you do have to wonder if perhaps it will soon be a victim of its own success. Anyway, with The Grudge, I avoided it because I wanted to see the original first but, with little access to it short of buying it I gave in and rented the remake ? so I can't compare the two, which is maybe a good thing. The film opens with a mystery and a good scare and really this is how it continues. Sadly the delivery took away from it; the flashbacks etc were reasonably easy to follow but it broke up the atmosphere and didn't allow a consistency that the actual plot could have had. Without this consistent atmosphere the film becomes more about "jump" scares rather than a constant chill and fear; this still works and I did find bits of it frightening but not to the point where it will stay with me in the way that the films I mentioned before do.Without a nice flow to the story, the characters are not as engaging as they could have been and I didn't feel the tragedy that is suggested by the script. The actors therefore mostly exist within the film rather than give strong performances. Gellar isn't a great actress but she can walk around looking scared and on edge ? luckily this is all she is asked to do. The rest of the cast are mostly familiar American faces, which I suppose helps it sell to the American multiplex audience. They all do the job well enough but none of them really got me into their characters although, like Gellar, they did well enough to help sustain the scares. The direction is good and it does build up the tension leading up to "jump" scares but from what I've heard it is shot for shot a copy of the original so you have to wonder why he bothered (other than the big pay cheque).Overall this is a good film and it delivers enough scares to be worth seeing; however those who have come to enjoy the formula of Japanese horrors will perhaps see it as rather watered down and having more in common with the American "sudden jump" method. The cast act scared but can't give us people although the director uses their fear well enough to satisfy those looking for a scare or two on a Saturday night.</fullReview>

		<date>2005-04-07</date>
		<username>Andy (film-critic)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>There is something evil there.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I will be completely honest with you, I watched this film with my finger on the fast-forward button pressed heavily so that the jumpy scenes wouldn't make me change my pants. I thought that this was one of the spookiest films that I have seen. Director Takashi Shimizu has done an excellent job remaking this film for American audiences. While some will argue that this is nothing more than just corporate Hollywood turning the cranks on audiences' wallets, I thought there was quite a bit of originality to this film. The institution of us seeing the demon or spirits before the characters do was something that I wasn't familiar with in other horror films. Normally, there is this big "jumping out of the darkness" scene that frightens everyone because they were not expecting it, but in The Grudge there was this element of "here I am" that frightened me more than most films do.Takashi Shimizu, the mastermind behind this film, also created the original Ju-on series that became extremely popular in Japan. This allowed his vision and purpose (with a larger budget) to continue. I enjoyed the fact that the original director was on board and that our American crew was in Japan. This took me away from the idea that this film was going to be nothing more than just a pro-America horror film. It took me to this unfamiliar place (building the fear) and showcased the talents of some unfamiliar/familiar American film actors working next to a complete Japanese crew. I thought that this kept the entire film grounded. It wasn't set in New York, there wasn't the scene of raw nudity at the beginning ? there wasn't the normal American structure to this film because we were not in America ? we were in Japan. This really helped me build the excitement and utter terror that I felt while watching this film. I was impressed.The acting, well, you don't go to a horror film expecting to see Oscar caliber acting. Gellar and Pullman knew that the horror genre is slowing coming into the limelight as a prominent figure in cinema (it was lacking for a couple of years there) and I think that is why they chose to do this project. Pullman wasn't anything to write home about, thought I was impressed to see him in this film. Gellar was the exact same. She did her part, collected her money, and went home. This wasn't what frightened me about this film. I didn't rent this movie to be blown away by the acting. I expected average acting and that is what I got. What I did go into this film expecting was to shake, shiver, and be frightened to turn off the lights after the film. That is exactly what I found. Takashi Shimizu did an excellent job of building that right amount of suspense, using amazing lighting, perfect sound, and some very freaky visuals. His knowledge and ability to bring us something new was extremely impressive and honest. Here is a director who was handed the money to make the film that he wanted, and while not everything was probably to his liking, it did open the door for more fans to enjoy his work. It also opened the door to more projects from his mind to be released. This could be the new face of cinematic horror, and I cannot wait to see what he has in store for us.Overall, I loved this movie. It was the exact level of fright that I was looking for. There were scenes that I never saw coming, there were elements that were unexpected and vividly raw, and it thankfully did not follow the ever-classic Hollywood horror formula. There was originality and emotion in this film that most horror directors do not give when dabbing in the horror genre. This was a great story, and I cannot wait to gather friends for a late night horror scream-fest featuring this film. From the opening scene, to the bus scene, to the opportunistic final moment, I had my finger on the fast-forward and I was scared. This did what it set out to do for me, and for that I can only praise this film! Grade: ***** out of *****</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Some very creepy moments</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>- The film's title refers to a Japanese myth involving the spirits of people who have died in "the grip of a powerful rage". Anyone who comes into contact with these spirits will die. The plot of The Grudge is very simple. An American exchange student, Karen (Sarah Michelle Gellar), living in Japan takes a job with a health care center. When one of the other workers doesn't show up, Karen is given her first solo assignment helping an older lady in her home. When Karen arrives, she immediately realizes that something is not quite right. What she doesn't realize is that this house is possessed by spirits who will kill anyone who sets foot inside.- Let me start by saying that I have not (as of 2/11/05) seen the original Japanese version. I plan to do so, hopefully, very soon. With that being said, I enjoyed The Grudge much more than I had expected. This is my first experience with Shimizu as a director, but I came away impressed. His has a nice ability to tell a story regardless of the language. The Grudge is one of the best examples of a non-linear story presentation that I can think of. As the movie progressed, it was a treat to watch Shimizu bring the pieces of the story together.- Another plus for The Grudge was Shimizu's decision (probably based on budgetary concerns as much as anything) to primarily use "real" effects and less CGI. The make-up on the Kayoka character, for example, created a far more unsettling image than the use of CGI could have. It was obvious that Kayoka was a real person, not just a computer image. The overuse or inappropriate use of CGI has ruined many modern horror movies.- There were, however, some areas where the movie could have been better. Gellar is one of the most unappealing leads in Hollywood. I've never understood what all the fuss is about. I always found her extremely annoying.- While the movie has many truly creepy (some were downright scary) scenes, the movie relies far too heavily on "jump moments". You know what I mean - a character opens a door and a cat jumps out (The Grudge actually features a cat jumping out of a closet). I've always thought that jump moments were a cheap way to illicit a response from the audience. A few jump moments can be good, but too many just becomes tiring.- Given that I wasn't expecting much, The Grudge was a lot of fun. I am looking forward to the sequel and to going back and discovering the original Japanese film - Ju-on: The Grudge.</fullReview>

"The Grudge" shows that a good horror movie doesn't need to be filled with monsters or gallons of blood, but that things you don't know or see can be more terrifying. 		<shortDescription>As scary as you thought horror movies would be when you were a child</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>POSSIBLE SPOILERS. Sometimes a film can succeed in one aspect so well that it's other considerable flaws do not matter that much. The Grudge is such a film. It's confusingly plotted and makes little sense. Apparently the director, in remaking his earlier versions of the story, supposedly tied things up better for this one. In that case, the earlier Japanese films must be COMPLETELY incoherent! The Grudge's acting is just passable. However, and this is big however, it is ABSOLUTELY TERRIFYING.The filmmakers set out to do nothing more than scare the socks of people who see the film. When so many horror films fail to scare, one that does is automatically criticized. It has been said that The Grudge is simply a collection of "BOO!" scenes, that it is too relentless, and that this undermines plot and characterization. Well, these are GOOD things. This film has no let-up. It doesn't even bother with a gradual build up. The scares come almost immediately and than hardly ever stop. Maybe it's silly that the ghosts are able to leave the house which they possess, but this makes them all the more scary. You just don't know when they will appear next.A few moments where CGI is employed fall a little flat, but who cares if one scare doesn't work when you know there will be be another just around the corner. The boy in the lift. The ghost in the bed. The ghost approaching the camera. The sudden glimpse on the bus.Of course people are constantly investigating odd noises and wandering off on their own. You often know when a scare is going to come, but this means that the audience is always kept on edge.It had been commented that some people have watched this film with an audience that sometimes laughed at the film. I think it was Alfred Hitchcock who said, when people laughed during one of his films, that it is a release, that they are actually probably scared. Don't try to follow the time shifting plot which raises more questions than it answers. Just enjoy the experience, possibly best at home on your own with the lights turned out.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>David Barbara (barbs@dragnet.com.au)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>startling</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Warning - spoilers follow.Having read a number of professional and user reviews highly critical of this film - I must say I'm surprised (the Ebert review was dismal). I haven't seen the Japanese originals - and I might have appreciated more backstory - especially relating to the nature of a Japanese curse - but I felt this was an outstanding film, replete with frights and fun, an old fashioned ghost story, reminiscent of The Sixth Sense and The Others.The ghosts are the stars - not shades or transparencies, these ghosts are beings of darkness and menace, with the power to mesmerise and terrify their victims. To see adults, reduced to shivering and impotent catatonia, is the essential anxiety of this film.Structurally intelligent, the use of flashbacks heightened the sense of dread - although we needed more on the nature of a curse - and how it might be lifted.For instance, I started thinking the curse manifests itself to its victims in an hallucinatory and suggestive way - so that, for those who have visited the house, the curse (the ghosts) become an inescapable part of them, rather than an external force - but it would have been nice to have this articulated - maybe by a Buddhist spiritualist (a theme touched on but not exploited).Also the ending was a disappointment - the film might have concluded at the incendiary point of flicking the Zippo into the petrol.See this film - for the gasps and scares - perhaps it is irritating that victims are drawn predictably to points of silence and darkness - but isn't that a part of the hypnotic charm of these internalised ghosts, the power to suggest and manipulate, before striking.I didn't laugh. I will never forget these ghosts.</fullReview>

		<score>0.2</score>
		<shortDescription>The chore</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This, the latest in the trend of remaking Japanese horror films, is a chore to watch. I can only hope the original is better than this, because if the original resembles this remake in any way, it signifies that Hollywood really has too much cash for its own good. It defies belief that a film could make one feel that a good half of its running time is redundant or unnecessary, yet another twenty minutes of well-made footage would make it seem a lot more coherent.Sarah Michelle Gellar, much like her hubby before her, seems to feel her star fading with every second of this feature. In this effort, she plays a young exchange student I will refer to as Buffy simply because she never gives the character enough of an individual personality to distinguish it from the role that made her famous. So anyway, Buffy works for what appears to be a healthcare service for invalids in Japan. Her task is to clean up the mess that these invalids make on themselves, or so the scenes here imply.Strangely, the job she goes to in this film involves a grandmother who she finds with no sign of relatives around. The way the family has disappeared is hinted at, but only revealed after what feels like eight hours has gone by. Adding to the pace problem is the fact that the time seems to jump back and forth like a breakdancer, accompanied by more fades to black than even Peter Jackson resorted to in order to compensate for his poor storytelling skills. Indeed, cause and effect are very hard to follow in this film. So much so that the deaths seem inconsequential.What The Grudge does have going for it are some very creepy effects shots. The sequence in which the shadow creeps up to a CCTV camera and its eyes suddenly become visible is one of the few parts of the film that lives up to the hype. If only the ending shot didn't seem like such an obvious pilfering of The Ring. When the dialogue comes along, it is either indecipherable or just plain boring. It is never a good idea to bore your audience so thoroughly in the first hour of your film and save all the explanations for thereafter. In all fiction, there is generally an unspoken rule that if you fail to hook your audience in the first couple of minutes, you never will succeed.I gave The Grudge a two out of ten. If Sarah Michelle Gellar was hoping to resurrect her career with this first-draft mess, then she is sorely mistaken. You could find much better things to do with ninety-plus minutes, including the performance of housework.</fullReview>

The camera was always in focus, the segues were nicely done, and everything seemed to be in frame when it was supposed to be. However, the special effects weren't scary at all. In fact, they were a little silly. The only thing that will have you jumping out of your seat is the loud sounds whenever an event of some kind takes place. It is just more annoying than anything else. What made this movie so bad was the stupid premise and even dumber script. It is truly the "Dumb and Dumber" of horror movies. The premise is that when a person dies in a rage that the place where they died is then haunted. If that were true then one out of every twenty homes in America would be unlivable. It is just a silly and untenable premise. I also couldn't believe some of the ignorant things the characters did and said in this movie. It was so bad it was funny! People in the theater were actually laughing.Perhaps this is what happens when we outsource our horror movies to Japan. I'll take a good old copy of "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" over these foreign films any day. Seriously, foreign writers and directors are just too mild and timid for American tastes. They are going to have to do a heck of a lot more then yell "Boo" to scare us! I hope this trash isn't an omen for the rest of the October movie season. Where is George A. Romero, Wes Craven, Tobe Hooper, and John Carpenter when you need them!Rating: 3/10. Don't waste your time or money. Too bad, I had such great hopes.</fullReview>

		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>All Style, No Substance</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I think, before you see this movie, you need to ask yourself exactly what you expect to get from it. Do you want a good movie, with an inventive plot, great acting, and imaginative directing? Or do you want a very pretty movie that will frighten you?'The Grudge' will scare you. If you truly allow yourself to be taken into that world, the silences and sudden bursts of activity are sure to startle you. The cinematography is disjointed and creepy enough to keep you reeling and interested from the first "ghost mauling" to the final scare.Unfortunately, in retrospect, "The Grudge" just disappoints. This is because, frankly, I just didn't care. Something that would have elevated this movie from a "cheap scare movie" to a great viewing experience would have been to include even a "smidge" of character development. Instead, we get to witness a cluster of caricatures being hunted by some supernatural force. The movie missed its chance to allow the audience to love the characters before they are torn away from us, which kept the film from being truly great.Also, like most horror movies, the story line finally comes into focus in the final third of the movie. When it inevitably happens in 'The Grudge,' everything seems to make sense...but it's something of a let down. "Oh...so...that was it?" I remember asking myself at the time. There are no surprises, or clever twists at the end. Just...a solid explanation that is sufficient, and nothing more.In all, I'm disappointed that the obviously talented filmmakers missed their opportunity to make a truly memorable film ? something along the lines of "The Ring" (although I believe that movie has serious shortcomings as well).Instead, I imagine "The Grudge" will most likely languish in the dark pit of "movies that did well in their first week, but dropped off the radar once something better came along." See it if you want to have a good, solid scare. Stay away if you desire a movie that is completely filling, and memorable.</fullReview>
