		<date>2005-01-30</date>
		<username>Random Task</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Irresistible Horror</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Ghosts stories are always creepy when it is in a decrepit old mansion at the far reaches of a small town. A ghost story that takes place in a modern Japanese bungalow in a residential district of one of the most densely populated cities in the world is creepier by putting the eerily aggravated poltergeists right next to everyday life. The frights come regularly and logically adhere to what little story there is. As a cinematic haunted hayride, this Americanized version of "The Grudge" succeeds with intelligence and reserve. It doesn't have anything to say, it just works like hell ? and succeeds - in making you feel terrified.The prologue is a gruesomely realistic death that does not hint at the supernatural, but the story is told out of sequence. The reasons behind everything become clear with time. It is a device that that keeps you very naturally involved through curiosity. We are introduced to the house in question. The living people are a transplanted American couple with a catatonic mother-in-law and a local visiting nurse (Yoko, played by Yoko Maki). Yoko comes to visit the mother-in-law and they are the only ones home when noises come from upstairs. Naturally, Yoko goes upstairs to check in the midst of checking an answering machine message; only to disappear with an astonished scream after meeting the first ghost, Kayako (Takako Fuji). The care center sends a replacement when Yoko fails to report the next day. Karen (Sarah Michelle Gellar) follows in Yoko's footsteps through the messy house to the immobile patient and falls into a shocked state after a glancing introduction to the horrors. Fortunately, her supervisor (Ted Raimi) has become suspicious of the absences and comes looking for her and gets the police involved. The terror comes frequently and unrelentingly after this encounter. It expands to consume the family, the investigating police officers and everyone Karen cares for in Tokyo. The bounds of this ghostly rage are not simply to be escaped by leaving the property, staying awake or lasting until sunrise.Director Takashi Shimizu keeps everyone reined in with the emphasis on minimalism in both production and acting in this Americanized follow-up to his original "Ju-On". There are special effects to enhance the supernatural, but the horror is done largely with the physical: lights turn off without explanation, a knock at the door comes impossibly fast after the person at the far end ends a phone call. This control urges the audience to anticipate and this ratchets up the tension. Bill Pullman has proved in various roles that he is adept at bringing quiet intensity to roles and he does here. Every character is given equal respect and screen time. Although this is an ensemble cast, the headlining star on the poster is Sarah Michelle Gellar. Clearly she and her agent are trying to edge her away from the threat of the "Buffy: The Vampire Slayer" role becoming a career buster. There are no sassy one-liners for her to fling at the monsters here. She is understated and finds a polite and frightened but upstanding demeanor to make Karen work. There is no melodramatic plot contrivance between events. People are drawn in by fear and curiosity. There are no ghost hunters, exorcists or supernatural experts of any kind here. The reasons for the ghosts' rage are hinted at through the characters' speculation and memories. Although I understand the original film is used as the back story."The Grudge" might not break new ground in creating a haunted house story, but it brings real terror, The camera isn't there to dazzle you, but rather to show you exactly what Shimizu wants you to see. You can't help but hold your breath for the next scare that comes forward to consume both characters and audience trapped like deer in headlights.7 out of 10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>ThrownMuse</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>lost in translation</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Karen is an American nursing student in Japan. When a catatonic woman's home caretaker goes missing, Karen fills in for her to get some school credits. She arrives and learns what the audience already knows: there is something evil lurking in the house.The American version of the Japanese "Ju On" is an entertaining and quite scary haunted house horror flick, but overall I left the theatre feeling unsatisfied.Comparisons to the American film The Ring seem inevitable before stepping foot in the theatre, as The Grudge is the first (in what could be a long line of) American-remade J-horror films since the huge success of The Ring. However, upon viewing The Grudge, such comparisons are fair and perhaps telling.The movie is scary, but mostly because it relies upon quick and consistent scare tactics (many shamelessly lifted from Ringu and The Ring) rather than by creating an unsettling atmosphere--which made the others movies so successful as horror films. That isn't to say that the scares in The Grudge aren't effective. The images are indeed creepy and caused me to scream-and-jump almost every time. However, there is hardly a build-up or engaging mystery to the back-story of "the grudge", and when it is revealed to Karen and the audience, it is really difficult to connect it with the terror we are witnessing.The movie doesn't offer much in terms of characterization, which is an important element in ghost stories. The audience isn't given much of an opportunity to sympathies with our leads. What we have is a handful of Americans living in Japan and being terrorized by two (croaking and meowing) Japanese grudge-holding ghosts. And their hair. From Kwaidan to Ringu, it seems that the female ghost with long black hair has long been a theme of Japanese horror movies. I am assuming that this is a cultural thing that I do not understand, as I am very unfamiliar with Japanese culture. In the American The Ring, most traces of Japanese culture are removed and the movie has no Japanese characters or mythology. Samara and her dark black hair covering her face are horrifying across the board, due to great effects and even better atmospheric build up. The Grudge goes right for the money shot: Look! She's being haunted by BLACK HAIR! The basic plot of The Grudge is apparently rooted in cultural mythology, but it is not expanded on in the film. It is briefly mentioned by the Japanese detective, who I found to be the most interesting character in the movie. The Japanese director (Takashi Shimizu, who helmed the Ju-On series), has said something to the effect of needing to change many elements of the original that would not appeal to American audiences--most obviously, by switching to an American cast. While it is obvious that changing the lead cast is for language and financial reasons, I still find it curious that it consists of three separate groups of people (Karen and Doug, the Williams family, Peter &amp; Maria), all of which are American. Some are getting along fine with their jobs, studies and the culture, others are experiencing "lost in translation" isolation.The Grudge has a fair share of scares, and it will have you jumping out of your seat. But by the end of this movie, one can't help but wonder about the underlying narrative about Americans and Japan, especially with regards to the current trend of Hollywood dishing out the dough to remake J-horror films.My rating: 5/10</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>The Real Ring 2</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Friends, this is a grand time to have a life in film. There are real advances still underway in this still new thing which is more about how we imagine than how we entertain ourselves.A particular device that interests me is the trick of transporting the viewer into the story in a way that actually works. Scary movies have this as a particular challenge because you cannot be afraid of something that doesn't actually threaten you.Check this out. It is a cross between the timeshifting usually associated with "Pulp Fiction" and the "watching" mechanism that worked so well for "Ringu." In this case, we have three watchers: the first two are a child who becomes an agent in the haunting, and Bill Pullman's character who stumbles onto the scene both as witness and cause. With this setup, we are introduced to a third "watcher," Geller's character. She has some elements of the detective, this inherited from many prior horror films, necessary because this is how much of the explanation is presented. But that's in the background here. Her main role is literally to exit her reality and enter a deeper reality as the watcher of the murder, watching also the first two watchers.In order to achieve this reality shift, the writer does something very clever. He slices the story up, shifting from time to time and among several related groups of people. This makes us watch closer, investing us deeper in the thing, but that could have been accomplished otherwise. The main effect of this shifting is to make it seem natural that as we shift, so can Gellar. When she does, she becomes us in a visceral way. Off-screen watchers get folded into on-screen watchers. Every image we have seen becomes a demon.Ted's Evaluation -- 3 of 3: Worth watching.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Ghastly Ghouls, Gargling Gophers</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>***spoilers***spoilers***spoilers***spoilersThere are bad movies and then there are movies which are so awful that they become affectionately comical in their ineptness. Such is the case with Columbia Pictures' 'The Grudge.' This cinematic atrocity began when an otherwise well intentioned American saw a Japanese made for TV film 'Ju-on' and was inspired to remake the movie in English. This began a virtual tsunami of bad decisions which circumnavigated the globe until it washed ashore in Orlando on October 21, 2004.The premise, and I use the word loosely, involves a house in Tokyo haunted by a skinny Momma ghost who looks like a cross between Margaret Cho and Alanis Morrisette, along with her ghastly sidekick a chubby, rambunctious but evil second grader. Is there anything scarier than a creepy 8 year old Japanese boy? Sure there is! Count Chocula comes to mind. With this whimsical bunch we must add a mysterious black cat who I have affectionately named Chim Chim. (Remember Speed Racer?) As you have already guessed, they were murdered in this domicile of doom and now desire to kill everyone who enters the premises. You see, as explained by a Japanese detective, when someone dies in a rage their ghost seeks revenge on everyone who steps on the property lines as defined by the county commissioner or something like that, I forget. The story begins innocently enough with acclaimed thespian Bill Pullman leaping to his death from a balcony. My guess is Bill Pullman got this job because of his kids begged him for a trip to Tokyo Disneyland. Next we endure the mildly interesting saga of Nurse Yoko, 'oh no don't go in there' screams the audience, but alas she heeds not the dire warnings and is predictably snuffed out like a magic lantern. About 30 minutes into the movie we finally see its American heroine Sarah Michelle Gellar as Karen. Sarah Michelle Gellar might be a competent actress but I could not help thinking of Buffy the Vampire Slayer, so much so that it was distracting. It is the equivalent to having Jennifer Anniston star in a movie about the adventures of six friends in New York. Try as you may, you just can't stop thinking about the other project which made her famous. But I digress, Karen, the nurse is hired as a replacement for the original care giver who disappeared at spooks r us. She snoops around, meets the ghosts, coma lady dies, and some other stuff happens. Watching the fair haired vixen searching for clues I half expected her to find the ghost and pull its mask off to reveal it was actually old man Gower who owned the abandoned amusement park! 'I would've gotten away with it too if it weren't for you meddling kids and that dog of yours!' Director Takashi Shimizu, who is vying to be the Ed Wood of Asia, made two unfortunate decisions involving sound. First, he choose to use a soundtrack only when someone is about to be killed. This is an excellent devise for obliterating any suspense because the audience gets a two minute warning to prepare for another miserably predictable murder. Second, he gave the ghosts a bizarre guttural noise that sounds like a gargling gopher. After the movie, I heard several people exiting the theatre making the sound and laughing.Sarah Michelle Gellar ends up being the sole survivor. And of course we learn that the fire she set to burn down the house was extinguished in time for the obligatory next chapter. However, considering the humorous reactions of the audience, they did not want a sequel but an apology. 'The Grudge' could be easily re-edited into a comedy, perhaps then it will be appreciated for its camp value. Baring that, this will go down as the greatest cinematic thriller since 'Godzilla vs. Megalon.' I would suggest waiting until the movie comes to your local discount theatre where it can receive the public ridicule it so richly deserves.</fullReview>

		<date>2013-10-14</date>
		<username>MaximumMadness</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>"The Grudge" is a decent Americanized Remake of the Japanese original, but it pales in comparison, and has many small issues holding it back from being a great remake...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is one of those reviews that's hard to write, if for no other reason than I feel that the score I am giving this film (a 6 out of 10) may be somewhat misleading. And it was a hard choice. I bopped back and forth between giving it an "average" score of 6 and a "pretty good" score of 7. But I had to fundamentally stick to my guns and give it the score I feel it deserves.Takashi Shimizu directs this 2004 American remake of his own 2002 release "Ju-On: The Grudge." (Which itself is the third film in an ongoing horror-movie series over in Japan, although it is the most well- known entry overseas, where the first two films have yet to see release) And it is a fairly faithful adaptation of his prior film, albeit with some large changes both in content and style to accommodate the mostly American production and the aim at a wider western audience.The film, much like Shimizu's original, follows a non-linear series of short story-vignettes set in Japan. These vignettes piece together like a puzzle to tell a much larger story of the effects a ghostly curse has on various people unfortunate enough to feel its grasp. The dominant focus is on Karen Davis, portrayed by Sarah Michelle Gellar, an exchange student in Japan who volunteers as a caregiver for elderly and disabled people to fulfill a college credit requirement. We also follow the impact the vengeful spirits have on the Williams family, an American family who was forced to relocate to Japan for work-related reasons. (Portrayed by actors including KaDee Strickland, William Mapother, Clea DuVall and Grace Zabriskie)The acting is uniformly good, although (similar to the original) some of the characters are under-developed and serve as little more than canon- fodder. Gellar sticks out as the only character with much development, and she does a great job with the material. Strickland, Duvall and Zabriskie also do great work with their small roles, which unfortunately almost exclusively boil down to nothing more than a few lines of dialog before screaming in fear during the scares. The other big standout is Japanese veteran actor Ryo Ishibashi as a troubled police detective all too familiar with the curse of the house. While he only has a few scenes, he's a lot of fun and does command the screen quite well.The production is also very competent, although I find it to be more troubled than the original. Shimizu, who was given a larger budget for this film and obviously a lot more "toys" and sets to play with behind- the-scenes, does set up his scares quite well. And his visual direction is generally well put-together. However, I did find that he almost degenerated slightly at times. His original film was a much more claustrophobic, slow-burning thriller, and it made the scares land so much harder as a result. This film feels more sanitized to me in terms of direction. His camera-work has a lot less "character" to it, and does feel a touch bland at times. But I won't complain too much.The rest of the production is quite nice. The set and costuming is very natural, the photography is basic and works for the atmosphere, and the music from veteran composer Christopher Young is quite nice.I suppose my fundamental problems with this film, despite a strong production and a capable cast, is that it feels like an unneeded and slightly inferior remake. Outside of the Americanized casting (which really felt pointless- why not just cast Japanese actors, or set the film in America with American actors?), the film is strongly similar to the original, with the only major changes being a few scenes that were dropped or added. And due to the more sanitized direction and loss of the "character" of the filmmaking, it just feels like an inferior rehash too often.I'm not saying it's a bad film. It's a very decent remake, and I do enjoy it, but it just didn't quite live up to the promise and quality of the original film. I know I shouldn't be thinking about that and that I should rate this film on its own merits, but it's just too big an issue to ignore. And honestly, if the original film had these issues, I wouldn't hold it in nearly as high a regard.As it stand, this is a remake worth checking out, as it is still definitely one of the stronger remakes to emerge from the "remake craze" of the past 15 years. (Which was arguably kicked into high gear by the outstanding American remake of "The Ring") But it isn't one of the best. (Though thankfully it is exponentially better than any of the trashy Platinum Dunes remakes that have been polluting cinemas for almost a decade now)I give this a decent, slightly above average 6 out of 10. (I'd give the original a good/very good 8 out of 10) It's creepy, it'll definitely give you chills... it's just not as good as the original.</fullReview>

		<username>Scott LeBrun (Hey_Sweden)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Above average American remake of a foreign film.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is due in no small part to the fact that the director of the original Japanese film, "Ju-On: The Gruge", Takashi Shimizu, is also at the reins of this effective shocker, which succeeds at melding a constant melancholy atmosphere with the traditional jump scares of the genre. It holds no surprises for anybody who has seen "Ju-On", but is still a good example of storytelling, as it moves from various points in time, telling of the assorted doomed individuals who come into contact with a Japanese house that had tragedy in its past. In 2004, an American exchange student named Karen (Sarah Michelle Gellar) does some investigating of her own, determined to find the cause of the horrific visions she's experiencing. Shimizu brings a great sense of style to this film, and, working from a screenplay by Stephen Susco (adapting Shimizu's original screenplay), does a nice job of capturing the experience of foreigners living and working in Japan. Even in its "unrated", extended form it's never as gory or exploitative as some viewers may expect, preferring to go for mood and atmosphere at all times. The director is also highly adept at building the mystery, as he reveals plot details a bit at a time and follows his characters on their doom laden paths. Moreover, we can like these characters and maintain genuine interest in seeing what happens to them. Special effects are generally well done, and one extremely effective touch is in seeing a supernatural occurrence actually show up on a surveillance tape. The integrated cast does very well under Shimizu's direction. The actors who played the ill fated family in his Japanese film - Yuya Ozeki, Takako Fuji, and Takashi Matsuyama - reprise their roles here, and Ryo Ishibashi of "Audition" fame plays the investigating detective. American cast members include Jason Behr, William Mapother, Clea DuVall, KaDee Strickland, Grace Zabriskie, Bill Pullman, Rosa Blasi, and Ted Raimi, whose brother Sam's company Ghost House produced the film. This has to rank as one of their finer efforts, a remake that is entirely respectful of its source and is just as legitimately creepy. Highly recommended. Eight out of 10.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2010-10-25</date>
		<username>muvcritic</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>No Terror Lost in Translation in The Grudge</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"The whole time I was in that house, I felt something was wrong." -- Karen (Sarah Michelle Gellar)It's a curious paradox. Human beings desperately hope there is a life after death, yet the core of all our nightmares is the terror evoked by anyone (or anything) that has actually managed to transcend death. It's instinctive: We just know that ain't supposed to happen. Ah, but if it didn't, there wouldn't be any need for Halloween -- currently, if polls and surveys are to be trusted, America's second favorite holiday -- or the creepy movies we like to celebrate it with.Like The Ring, The Grudge is a transliteration of an original Japanese film which deals with a fury that not even death can extinguish. And, like its predecessor, The Grudge combines time-tested techniques for startling an audience with an impressive and distinct visual style that takes those techniques and pushes the envelope, as well as recasting the story with better known occidental faces -- in this case, Sara Michelle Gellar, who has forged a career by fighting the supernatural in five years of starring as Buffy, The Vampire Slayer, and for the toddler set, the live-action Scooby Doo franchise. Well, I'm here to tell you that, hopefully, no toddlers will be attending The Grudge because, if they do, don't count on 'em sleeping through the night anytime soon. Geller stars as Karen, an American student in Japan who supplements her income by providing at-home care for housebound, English-speaking invalids. When one of her co-workers evidently fails to report for work, she is sent to fill in. It's, of course, immediately evident that something isn't right with the suburban home, as she and other witnesses keep seeing an eerie, noncommunicative Japanese child accompanied by a yowling black cat. Of course, the audience knows immediately that the boy and his ill-tempered pet are dead as doornails, with Karen left to solve the mystery of why their spirits are so restless.I'll confess right now that, while I've never experienced anything that I even remotely suspected was supernatural, I'm a sucker for scary movies, and writer/director Takashi Shimizu (who also helmed the Japanese original) knows all the right buttons to push, and then some. I'll qualify by saying that close friends have told me about some nightmarish apparitions, two even reporting manifestations not unlike several pictured in this film. I've even arrived on the scene scant minutes after such encounters, but, as I was told once by a psychic, I'm so insensitive and close-minded to the world around me that I'm completely incapable of perceiving the paranormal. Well, good, because if there are horrific things like these prowling around, I don't want to see 'em. Except, of course, in movies.However, the principal difference between "real" hauntings and cinematic ones, at least of what I've read and been told by supposed witnesses about things that jump out of closets, is that's all they ever really do. Any actual harm to a human being resulting from an encounter with a ghost is always personal injury due to trying to get the hell out of the house. But, if you didn't have actual victims in a film, there wouldn't be enough conflict, so movie ghosts, it seems, must have homicidal intent to be interesting. Accordingly, the wraiths in The Grudge are intent on drafting as many living humans to join their undead existence as possible, and they're pretty successful.The only place The Grudge really breaks down is in repeating the mistake of so many American horror movies, which is the Law of Dark Places: If there is somewhere you are convinced is inhabited by a dangerous maniac/demon/monster, as many of your cast members as possible must go there alone, and preferably at night, so they can be conveniently picked off one by one. In the last 20 minutes, no less than three characters, who all know what awaits them, race off alone to the haunted house, in the dead of night. There may admittedly be some justification because one of Shimizu's dramatic innovations is the realization that, having once visited the house, its evil will follow you wherever you go and you can never be safe again, and there's some mighty creepy stuff going on in Japanese office towers, commuter trains, even a local police station. Still, who in his right mind is going to go back in a house that is the very nexus of the evil?Certainly not yours truly, and I will readily admit I completely agreed with the members of the audience exhorting the characters, especially Geller's, not to return. The Grudge is an audience participation film, which you will certainly not get anywhere near the full impact of if you wait to see it on video in the safety of your own home. Fear, like humor, is a vastly more potent emotion when experienced communally.</fullReview>
	</review>

This is a movie to feed your paranoia, your fear of darkness and of empty houses. It makes you watch the door to your cellar or the attic with goosebumps, lets you hear sounds in the night and makes you feel watched from behind. In short: IT GIVES YOU THE CREEPS.Notably, the movie does not rely only on the subtle effects of old movies to build up tension: not just quick glances of creeping shadows to hint at a monstrosity. You'll get all that, but sooner or later you'll be confronted with "the monster" face-to-face: no highly sophisticated latex Hollywood masks (that are more funny than scary), no rotten flesh and all that stuff, but still VERY SCARY (don't ask me why though).I must admit, though, that some of the surprise effects are very predictable, as many critics have observed before me. And yet, you won't mind them, because as opposed to many of the other movies where there is just the odd dismembered hand floating into screen to give you a quick scare without any real "justification" in the story, these shock effects just belong there: they are not scary because they are "surprising", but because YOU KNOW YOU CAN'T AVOID THEM. And finally, Sarah Michelle Gellar turned out to be a convincing actor after all ;)I bought the DVD the moment it appeared on the market and later also the Director's cut (which is not worth the extra money, unless you haven't seen "Ju-On" or liked it better: it is much closer to the original) and I MUST HAVE WATCHED THE MOVIE 5 TIMES BY NOW AND IT IS STILL CREEPY.If you're looking for subtle scares and, like me, are longing for the "good ole" creeps of early horror movies, this is just the film for you.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>yet another ho-hum horror film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>At exactly 17 minutes and 45 seconds into "The Grudge," the ever-reliable cat jumps out of a closet and scares somebody. I tell you this only so that you will know when you will be able to take a quick refreshment and/or restroom break and not miss anything. It also pretty much underscores the modus operandi of this film, which is "don't bother with something new when something old will do." For although "The Grudge" is a remake of a recent Japanese film ("Ju-On," made by the same director, Takashi Shimizu), there really isn't anything here that we haven't seen hundreds of times before in haunted house movies made east of the International Date Line.The bland Sarah Michelle Gellar plays a young foreign exchange student living in Japan who volunteers as a care worker in her spare time. When she is sent to the home of a strangely "lethargic" woman, Gellar begins to suspect that there is something not quite right about the residence. From then on, she and several other people, who also share a connection with the house, are haunted by a ghoulish specter who keeps popping up in the strangest places and at the most inopportune moments to exact her revenge for being done away with in an untimely manner (although none of the people she pesters had anything to do with her demise).Although there are a few mildly suspenseful moments scattered throughout the film, "The Grudge" is simply too derivative and too hackneyed to register much of an impact on our psyches, with a great deal of its imagery ripped-off from that seminal horror film "Carnival of Souls." The story makes very little sense when you start to analyze it seriously and, after all the huffing and puffing to arrive at a stunning climax, the ending deflates like a slowly leaking balloon. I haven't seen the original version, so I have no idea how it compares to this one. But I can hardly imagine it was anywhere near as undistinguished and lackluster as this one is (or else why remake it?). Even with the same director at the controls, perhaps something simply got lost in the translation.</fullReview>

The music tells us something will happen, the camera stays close to the character so things can enter the screen quite suddenly and then... well, most of the time something that has nothing to do with the story gives a reaction to most members from the audience. 'The Grudge' has these moments, although most of them actually do show us events that involve the story. I just didn't care much since we have the same approach here.Up to a level I guess I enjoyed it. For me some of the fun came from guessing what would jump in front of the camera, but again, my friend was actually scared at times. Therefore I must admit this film does the job better than most horror films. Films like 'The Texas Chainsaw Massacre' or 'Wrong Turn' depend on gore, this one at least has the nerve to depend on the old simple tricks (keeping it a PG-13 rated film), apparently succeeding from time to time. If you normally enjoy this kind of film you will like this very much. If you want an interesting and intelligent story you should avoid this, it is as simple as that.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2005-02-22</date>
		<username>Phil Sneyd (movie-geek)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>"The whole time I was in that house I felt something was wrong."</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Hi. I live in Tokyo, and I just went to see The Juon at a cinema in Ikebukuro.As a horror fan who is aware of and disappointed by the fact that 95% of horror films are pure and utter shite, I am constantly on the lookout for a decent, full-blooded, and - damn it - scary, horror flick. The Juon is it. At last, another gem to prove that horror is not dead and will continue to shamble on zombie-like producing the occasional spine-chilling shocker which makes the wait worth it.It may be true that there are some cultural factors involved (which might explain the negative reviews from some of our western friends in the discussion boards), and I will readily admit that perhaps it had such a big impact on me because I could relate to so much of it.I mean, the interior of the house looks exactly like my apartment; tatami floors, sliding doors and closets, and so on; the Tokyo scenes were all familiar; the freaky wild-cats-in-heat noises that sound like babies from hell all over the city during mating season; I know what it feels like to be a fish-out-of-water gaijin in Japan (I'm Irish) and like Bill Pulman's character I am an English teacher.Without wishing to create any spoilers for those who haven't seen it, I'm sure those who have will appreciate why I was suitably freaked out.There is often terror to be found in the familiar (just ask Stephen King), so perhaps it was a little too unfamiliar for western audiences.Also, people complain that they can't understand this or that, and demand explanations. In Japanese horror, it is the understated, the inexplicable, the unknown, that makes it scary. The same thing happened with The Ring. People wanted explanations for everything: who is Sadako? What motivates her? A lot of these questions were addressed in the American remake, with the result that the clarified story was too ridiculous and unbelievable. Basically, they tried to explain too much.On the other hand, it should be borne in mind that a lot of the negative reviews (saying it's not scary, etc.) are referring to the American version of the movie only. If you check out the "trivia" section in the menu on the left of this IMDb page, you'll find that the movie was released cut after American test screen audiences viewed it, presumably because it was too scary.Can't have that now, a scary horror movie. I know, I know. I'm scratching my head too.If you're a horror fan, do yourself a favour and try to get a hold of the uncut Japanese version (ie; the real movie). I'm not sure, but it might crop up on DVD. Now that is what scary is all about.Forget 'Freddy vs Jason', or 'Jason goes to Space' or whatever. I give The Juon 10 out of 10.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2005-02-06</date>
		<username>abgkasjlkasjla</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>I'm not sure...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Coming back from the cinema after seeing this film, I'm not quite sure what to make of it. I guess it was on the way back, through the dark, empty streets, that I realized something was missing. Something important, maybe even crucial, something that needs to be there after just seeing a horror film on the silver screen. I wasn't scared. I wasn't looking over my shoulder, I wasn't listening for any strange sounds, I wasn't even looking twice on any person I walked past on the way. I'm a sucker for scary movies, I'll tell you that right away; but this didn't scare me. It startled me, made me jump in my seat, but that's it. That's what the 'horror' portion of the film is, a long series of jumps. There's nothing wrong with that... but that's just all it is. No real gore, no atmosphere, no psychological terror... just jumps. I'm not saying that any of the aforementioned qualities would make a better horror movie... but they probably would make it more 'full'. The truth is, sadly, there's nothing in this movie that will really stay in your mind for very long after you leave the cinema... if there's still anything after the end credits. Luckily, the director rarely resorts to the cheap jump scares... few of the shocks come from a cat jumping down from a shelf or a friend appearing behind the main character, reaching out and grabbing their shoulder. Most of the time, when you jump, it's because someone just died or something genuinely disturbing just happened. The worst thing about the jump scares is probably that you can only watch and still... well... jump, because after that, you'll know where and when the jumps will occur. What makes this watchable apart from the undeniable effect of the jump scares is that, on some level, it manages to appear deeper than it is, without being condescending. There are plenty of little details, stuff that only the most watchful eye will notice. The way the story is told is masterful in a way... very little dialog is used to explain it. A series of situations and powerful acting tell us far more than Hollywood-like dialog(which the film has slim to none of) could. The plot isn't deep, and it isn't really the driving force in the film, but there's enough of it and it's mostly good. The acting ranges, but most of it's pretty good. The characters are well-written and interesting, but most of them just aren't developed enough for us to care about whether they live or die, which is a fatal mistake on the directors part, because it kills a lot of the suspense. The non-linear time-line is presented so casually that many viewers will probably be thrown off(I know I was), and not know when exactly something is happening. One final note before I pass verdict; personally I thought it was a mistake to cast Joxer of Xena: Warrior Princess(Ted Raimi) in a serious horror film, but at least his role isn't very big. Also, he *is* the executive producer's brother, and, well, that's pretty much Hollywood in a nutshell. All in all, the film is pretty much worth watching, but probably only once, and with reasonable expectations. I recommend it to fans of the Japanese horror films, keeping in mind that this is an Americanized version(but done by the same director). However, even though I haven't seen them myself, you should probably see the original Ju-on film(s). Also, personally I don't think this is as good an American remake of a Japanese horror film as The Ring. Go see that first, as well. 7/10</fullReview>
	</review>

I've long given up on relying on others to determine a decent movie and this one (from a true horror fan) is brilliant stuff and will be one of my favourites for quite some time. I also benefited from an audience that was sucked up by the movie in the cinema... the guy next to me jumped out of the seat only a few minutes in, people were screaming and the end was met with a hushed almost nervous silence.The movie was a huge success 'despite' the unimaginative public and that shows just how impressive it is - I have heard people laughed at certain scenes that one would consider far from amusing.. examples of either humour to hide nervousness or conditioning to all types of horrendous acts. Sorry, Susan, but?bye-bye!Anyhow, now that the police can't get any answer from Susan, and now that the police have figured out that Jennifer and Matthew are dead along with a strange piece of a body on the ground in the attic with them, what are they to do? 		<username>The_Void</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>A surprisingly good remake for a change!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I've been less than impressed with the recent crop of Japanese horror films. Perhaps it's just because I don't like ghost stories much, but I think that for a bunch of films that are so highly acclaimed; they fall massively short of the mark, especially since they're so similar to one another. Another thing I've been less than impressed with is the way that America have been snapping up everything from Asia that they can get their hands on and remaking it. The Ring was remade with disastrous results, but nevertheless we find ourselves here with the latest remake; The Grudge. I haven't seen the original version of this film (and am in no rush to), but to my surprise this film is actually quite good. The Grudge stars Sarah Michele Geller (from that Buffy rubbish) and it follows her as she goes to work for a woman in Japan who needs caring for. The Grudge professes that whenever someone is killed in a fit of rage, a curse is broken and the spirit lay dormant for someone to enter that curse. Something that Buffy has just done...The Eastern setting helps to add mystery to the already mysterious plot. It is customary for American remakes to be moved to America, but the fact that this one didn't get relocated is much to it's credit. The film's effects are really good, and some parts where the ghosts are shown are genuinely quite creepy, due to the effects. However, the film goes a bit overboard with it's scares at times, and it goes for the money shot too often. For example; tension is mounting and then suddenly! ...the phone rings. It's such a waste, and although it does help to build the unease; the film would have been much better served if it kept the tension building, rather than diffusing it every five seconds with another nonchalant happening. The music in the film is very good, however, and it always serves in adding to the bewilderment that the film is keen to capitalise on. The Grudge relies a lot on it's sense of dread, and the music helps to capture that.The film isn't a complete whole, mostly for the reasons mentioned. However; as remakes of Japanese films go, this is a very good example and I recommend this one over most other films in it's class.</fullReview>
	</review>

Only in this case, the duplicates all happen to be American citizens living in Japan. And what's up with that, anyway? Is the point of view of this movie that if Americans decide to go live in Japan, they will have to contend with vengeful rage-ghosts? Does the tourism council even mention it? And fair warning, don't eat any rich cream soups or drink a large glass of strawberry Nestle's Quik before seeing it, as the slow motion belch sound effect that is so pervasive in the movie (both movies actually) is likely to have an ipecac like effect on you.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>This is a cultural twist on the too familiar haunted house story...but with an abundance of attitude. You will jump; you will think your heart has stopped; and your goosebumps will have goosebumps. Based on the Japanese powerhouse JU-ON:THE GRUDGE(1963), in a modest house in Tokyo resides hidden terror. It is possessed by a plague on the lives of those who enters it. "The Grudge" causes victims to die in a powerful rage and like a virus becomes a chain of horror as it moves from one victim to the next.An American exchange student(Sarah Michelle Gellar)studying social work in Japan agrees to care for an elderly woman(Grace Zabriskie)victimized by more than her catatonic being. The house should otherwise be deserted when the young woman begins to hear the sound of scratching and upon investigating she is starkly introduced to supernatural horror. The story might lose something in translation; but what makes this movie so creepy and heart pounding is the superior collaboration of lighting, sound and camera editing. The atmosphere is confusing and profound. The only way to prepare for this suspenseful horror roller coaster is Prozac and a change of underwear.Also in the cast are: Jason Behr, William Mapother, Clea DuVall and Bill Pullman. Kudos to director Takashi Shimizu.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>English-speaking version of Japanese movie.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"The Grudge" probably doesn't translate very well as a title, because the English-speaking world doesn't use the word in the same context. This is a remake of a Japanese movie, by the same Japanese director. Which was a good idea, because otherwise most of us would never have seen it with subtitles. It is based on Japanese myths which are explained in the DVD extras, which is almost essential for fully understanding the story. It is appropriately scary, and begs for watching a comedy next, before going to bed. I didn't particularly like Gellar in the lead role, but I suppose she was OK.SPOILERS. Set in Tokyo, early in the story we see Peter (Bill Pullman) acting strange on his upper floor patio, then without saying anything he just sort of bends over and slides over the edge, down to his death in the street below. We don't find out why until near the end, when it turns out he was the lover of a Japanese woman who, along with her small son and pet cat, were killed by the enraged husband, who then killed himself. Inspired by an old Japanese story of a king who took a similar revenge after a subject of his beat him in chess. According to myth, the building then takes revenge, it holds the "grudge", not a person. So the house of the Japanese family is haunted by the dead son and cat, and everyone who enters the house will die. Gradually all the new residents are done in, and as the movie ends Karen (Gellar), studying in Tokyo and doing volunteer work, will likely be next. The point being the building doesn't discriminate between good and bad people, they all die. And in the beginning, Peter was possessed to kill himself because he was responsible for the husband's rage that resulted in his family's deaths.</fullReview>
